The center of Cambodian archaeological preservation and exhibition. Easily accessed. Really crowded with students and tourists. It provides audio-guide. The collections are mostly archaeological. The building itself is a museum collection; beautiful and grandeur.

text.wiki:
Phnom Penh (; Khmer: ភ្នំពេញ, romanized: phnum pɨñ, IPA: [pʰnʊm ˈpɨɲ]; literally "Penh's Hill"), formerly known as Krong Chaktomuk Serimongkul (Khmer: ក្រុងចតុមុខសិរីមង្គល, lit. 'City of the Brahma's Faces') or shortly known as Krong Chaktomuk (Khmer: ក្រុងចតុមុខ), is the capital and most populous city in Cambodia. Phnom Penh has been the national capital since French colonization of Cambodia, and has grown to become the nation's economic, industrial, and cultural center.
Once known as the "Pearl of Asia," it was considered one of the loveliest French-built cities in Indochina in the 1920s. Phnom Penh, along with Siem Reap and Sihanoukville, are significant global and domestic tourist destinations for Cambodia. Founded in 1372, the city is noted for its historical architecture and attractions. It became the national capital in 1434 following the fall of Angkor, and remained so until 1497. It regained its capital status during the French colonial era in 1865. There are a number of surviving French colonial buildings scattered along the grand boulevards.
On the banks of the Tonlé Sap, Mekong, and Bassac Rivers, Phnom Penh is home to more than 2 million people, approximately 14% of the Cambodian population.


== Etymology ==
Phnom Penh (literally, 'Penh's Hill') takes its name from the present Wat Phnom ('Hill Temple'). Legend has it that in 1372, a wealthy widow named Lady Penh found a Koki tree floating down the Tonle Sap river after a storm. Inside the tree were four bronze Buddha statues and a stone statue of Vishnu. Daun Penh ordered villagers to raise the height of the hill northeast of her house and used the Koki wood to build a temple on the hill to house the four Buddha statues, and a shrine for the Vishnu image slightly lower down. The temple became known as Wat Phnom Daun Penh, which is now known as Wat Phnom, a small hill 27 metres (89 ft) in height.
Phnom Penh's official name, in its short form, is Krong Chaktomok (Khmer: ក្រុងចតុមុខ) meaning "City of Four Faces". Krong Chaktomuk is an abbreviation of the full name which was given by King Ponhea Yat, Krong Chaktomuk Mongkol Sakal Kampuchea Thipadei Serey Thereak Borvor Inthabot Borei Roth Reach Seima Maha Nokor (Khmer: ក្រុងចតុមុខមង្គលសកលកម្ពុជាធិបតី សិរីធរបវរ ឥន្ទបត្តបុរី រដ្ឋរាជសីមាមហានគរ, Khmer pronunciation: [ˌkɾongˌcaʔtoʔmʊk̚ˌmʊŋkʊlˌsaʔkɑlˌkampuʔciəˌtʰɨp̚paʔdəjˌseʔɾəjˌtʰe͡aʔɾe͡aʔˌbɑːvɑːˌənte͡aʔpatˌboʔɾəjˌɾoat̚tʰaʔˌɾiəcˌsəjmaːˌmɔhaːˌnɔˈkɔː]). This loosely translates as "The place of four rivers that gives the happiness and success of Khmer Kingdom, the highest leader as well as impregnable city of the God Indra of the great kingdom".


== History ==
First recorded a century after it is said to have taken place, the legend of the founding of Phnom Penh tells of a local woman, Penh (commonly referred to as Daun Penh ("Grandmother Penh" or "Old Lady Penh") in Khmer), living at Chaktomuk, the future Phnom Penh. It was the late 14th century, and the Khmer capital was still at Angkor near Siem Reap 350 km (217 mi) to the north. Gathering firewood along the banks of the river, Lady Penh spied a floating koki tree in the river and fished it from the water. Inside the tree she found four Buddha statues and one of Vishnu.
The discovery was taken as a divine blessing, and to some a sign that the Khmer capital was to be brought to Phnom Penh from Angkor. To house the new-found sacred objects, Penh raised a small hill on the west bank of the Tonle Sap River and crowned it with a shrine, now known as Wat Phnom at the north end of central Phnom Penh. "Phnom" is Khmer for "hill" and Penh's hill took on the name of the founder, and the area around it became known after the hill.
Phnom Penh first became the capital of Cambodia after Ponhea Yat, king of the Khmer Empire, moved the capital from Angkor Thom after it was captured and destroyed by Siam a few years earlier. There is a stupa behind Wat Phnom that houses the remains of Ponhea Yat and the royal family as well as the remaining Buddhist statues from the Angkorean era. In the 17th century, Japanese immigrants also settled on the outskirts of present-day Phnom Penh. A small Portuguese community survived in Phnom Penh until the 17th century, undertaking commercial and religious activity in the country.
Phnom Penh remained the royal capital for 73 years, from 1432 to 1505. It was abandoned for 360 years (from 1505 to 1865) by subsequent kings due to internal fighting between the royal pretenders. Later kings moved the capital several times and established their royal capitals at various locations in Tuol Basan (Srey Santhor), Pursat, Longvek, Lavear Em and Oudong.
It was not until 1866, under the reign of King Norodom I (1860–1904), the eldest son of King Ang Duong, who ruled on behalf of Siam, that Phnom Penh became the permanent seat of government and capital of Cambodia, and also where the current Royal Palace was built. Beginning in 1870, the French colonial authorities turned a riverside village into a city where they built hotels, schools, prisons, barracks, banks, public works offices, telegraph offices, law courts, and health services buildings. In 1872, the first glimpse of a modern city took shape when the colonial administration employed the services of French contractor Le Faucheur to construct the first 300 concrete houses for sale and rental to Chinese traders.
By the 1920s, Phnom Penh was known as the "Pearl of Asia", and over the next four decades, Phnom Penh continued to experience rapid growth with the building of railways to Sihanoukville and Pochentong International Airport (now Phnom Penh International Airport). Phnom Penh's infrastructure saw major modernisation under the rule of Sihanouk.During the Vietnam War, Cambodia was used as a base by the People's Army of Vietnam (PAVN) and the Viet Cong (VC) and thousands of refugees from across the country flooded the city to escape the fighting between their own government troops, the PAVN/VC, the South Vietnamese and its allies and the Khmer Rouge and the American air strikes. By 1975, the population was 2–3 million, the bulk of whom were refugees from the fighting. The Khmer Rouge cut off supplies to the city for more than a year before it fell on April 17, 1975. Reports from journalists stated that the Khmer Rouge shelling "tortured the capital almost continuously," inflicting "random death and mutilation" on millions of trapped civilians. The Khmer Rouge forcibly evacuated the entire city after taking it, in what has been described as a death march: François Ponchaud wrote that "I shall never forget one cripple who had neither hands nor feet, writhing along the ground like a severed worm, or a weeping father carrying his ten-year old daughter wrapped in a sheet tied around his neck like a sling, or the man with his foot dangling at the end of a leg to which it was attached by nothing but skin"; Jon Swain recalled that the Khmer Rouge were "tipping out patients from the hospitals like garbage into the streets....In five years of war, this is the greatest caravan of human misery I have seen." All of its residents, including the wealthy and educated, were evacuated from the city and forced to do difficult labour on rural farms as "new people". Tuol Sleng High School was taken over by Pol Pot's forces and was turned into the S-21 prison camp, where people were detained and tortured. Pol Pot sought a return to an agrarian economy and therefore killed many people perceived as educated, "lazy" or political enemies. Many others starved to death as a result of failure of the agrarian society and the sale of Cambodia's rice to China in exchange for bullets and weaponry. The former high school is now the Tuol Sleng Genocide Museum, where Khmer Rouge torture devices and photos of their victims are displayed. Choeung Ek (The Killing Fields), 15 kilometers (9 mi) away, where the Khmer Rouge marched prisoners from Tuol Sleng to be murdered and buried in shallow pits, is also now a memorial to those who were killed by the regime.
The Khmer Rouge were driven out of Phnom Penh by the PAVN in 1979, and people began to return to the city. Vietnam is historically a state with which Cambodia has had many conflicts, therefore this liberation was and is viewed with mixed emotions by the Cambodians. A period of reconstruction began, spurred by the continuing stability of government, attracting new foreign investment and aid by countries including France, Australia, and Japan. Loans were made from the Asian Development Bank and the World Bank to reinstate a clean water supply, roads and other infrastructure. The 1998 Census put Phnom Penh's population at 862,000; and the 2008 census was 1.3 million.


== Geography ==
Phnom Penh is in the south-central region of Cambodia, and is fully surrounded by Kandal Province. The municipality is on the banks of the Tonlé Sap, Mekong, and Bassac Rivers. These rivers provide freshwater and other natural resources to the city. Phnom Penh and the surrounding areas consist of a typical flood plain area for Cambodia. Although Phnom Penh is at 11.89 metres (39 ft) above the river, monsoon season flooding is a problem, and the river sometimes overflows its banks.
The city, at 11.55°N 104.91667°E﻿ / 11.55; 104.91667 (11°33' North, 104°55' East), covers an area of 678.46 square kilometres (262 sq mi), with some 11,401 hectares (28,172 acres) in the municipality and 26,106 ha (64,509 acres) of roads. The agricultural land in the municipality amounts to 34.685 km2 (13 sq mi) with some 1.476 km2 (365 acres) under irrigation.


=== Climate ===
Phnom Penh has a tropical wet and dry climate (Köppen climate classification Aw). The climate is hot year-round with only minor variations. Temperatures typically range from 22 to 35 °C (72 to 95 °F) and weather is subject to the tropical monsoons. The southwest monsoon blows inland bringing moisture-laden winds from the Gulf of Thailand and Indian Ocean from May to November. The northeast monsoon ushers in the dry season, which lasts from December to April. The city experiences the heaviest precipitation from September to October with the driest period in January and February.
The city has two distinct seasons. The rainy season, which runs from May to November, sees high temperatures accompanied by high humidity. The dry season lasts from December to April; when overnight temperatures can drop to 22 °C (72 °F).


== Administration ==

Phnom Penh is a municipality of area 678.46 square kilometres (261.95 sq mi) with a government status equal to that of Cambodian provinces. The municipality is divided into 14 administrative divisions called khans (sections). The sections are subdivided into 105 sangkats (quarters), and further subdivided into 953 phums (villages).  All khans are under the governance of the Phnom Penh Municipality. Dangkao, Meanchey, Porsenchey, Sen Sok and Russei Keo are considered the outskirts of the city.
The municipality is governed by the governor who acts as the top executive of the city as well as overseeing the Municipal Military Police, Municipal Police, and Bureau of Urban Affairs. Below the governor is the first vice governor and five vice governors. The chief of cabinet, who holds the same status as the vice governors, heads the cabinet consisting of eight deputy chiefs of cabinet who in turn are in charge of the 27 administrative departments. Every khan (district) also has a chief.


== Demographics ==
As of 2019, Phnom Penh had a population of 2,129,371 people, with a total population density of 3,136 inhabitants per square kilometre in a 679 square kilometres (262 sq mi) city area. The population growth rate of the city is 3.92%. The city area has grown fourfold since 1979, and the metro area will continue to expand in order to support the city's growing population and economy.
Phnom Penh is mostly inhabited by Cambodians (or Khmers). They represent 90% of the population of the city. There are large minorities of Chinese, Vietnamese, and other small ethnic groups who are Thai, Budong, Mnong Preh, Kuy, Chong, and Chams. The state religion is Theravada Buddhism. More than 90% of the people in Phnom Penh are Buddhists. Chams have been practicing Islam for hundreds of years. Since 1993, there has also been an increase in the practice of Christianity which was practically wiped out after 1975 when the Khmer Rouge took over. The official language is Khmer, but English and French are widely used in the city.
The number of slum-inhabitants at the end of 2012 was 105,771, compared with 85,807 at the start of 2012.Note: As stated in the "History" paragraph (The 1998 Census put Phnom Penh's population at 862,000; and the 2008 census was 1.3 million.) the information collides with the information provided in the "Historical population" table. Needs editing.


== Politics ==

 
Phnom Penh is allocated 12 seats in the National Assembly, making it the largest constituency.


=== Members of Parliament ===


== Economy ==

Phnom Penh is Cambodia's economic centre as it accounts for a large portion of the Cambodian economy. Double-digit economic growth rates in recent years have triggered an economic boom in Phnom Penh, with new hotels, restaurants, schools, bars, high rises and residential buildings springing up in the city.
The economy is based on commercial interests such as garments, trading, and small and medium enterprises. In the past few years the property business has been booming, with rapidly increasing real estate prices. Tourism is also a major contributor in the capital as more shopping and commercial centres open, making Phnom Penh one of the major tourist destinations in South East Asia along with Siem Reap and Sihanoukville. According to the World Travel and Tourism Council, tourism made up 19.2 percent (US$2,053 million) of Cambodia's GDP in 2009 and accounts for 13.7 percent of total employment. One of the most popular areas in Phnom Penh for tourists is Sisowath Quay, alongside the Tonle Sap River. Sisowath Quay is a five kilometre strip of road that includes restaurants, bars, and hotels.The US$2.6 billion new urban development, Camko City, is meant to bolster the city landscape. The Bureau of Urban Affairs of Pnochina Penh Municipality has plans to expand and construct new infrastructure to accommodate the growing population and economy. High rise buildings will be chinesely constructed at the entrance of the city and near the lakes and riverbanks. Furthermore, new roads, canals, and a railway system will be used to connect Camko City and Phnom Penh.
Other projects include:

Grand Phnom Penh International City (under construction)
De Castle Royal Condominium (Completed)
Gold Tower 42 (On hold 32 floors construction begins again in the mid of 2018)
OCIC Tower (Completed)
Kokling super second floor house
Vattanac Capital Tower (completed)
The Bridge (Completed)
The Peak (under construction)
With booming economic growth seen since the 1990s, new shopping venues have opened: Sorya Center Point, Aeon Mall Phnom Penh, Aeon Mall Sen Sok City, Olympia Mall, and Parkson Mall (under construction). Many international brands have opened such as Mango, Salvatore Ferragamo, Hugo Boss, Padini Concept Store, Lily, Timberland, Jimmy Choo, CC Double O, MO, Brands Outlet, Nike, Converse, Pony, Armani Exchange, and Super Dry.
The tallest skyscraper in Phnom Penh is Vattanac Capital Tower at a height of 188 metres (617 ft), dominating Phnom Penh's skyline with its neighbour skyscraper Canadia Tower (OCIC Tower). The tower was completed in December 2014. Modern high rises have been constructed all around the city, not concentrated in any one particular area.
The Central Market Phsar Thmei is a tourist attraction. The four wings of the yellow colored market are teeming with numerous stalls selling gold and silver jewelry, antique coins, clothing, clocks, flowers, food, fabrics and shoes. Phsar Thmei is undergoing under a major renovation, along with the creation of newer stalls.


== Education ==


=== Universities and colleges ===


=== Primary and secondary schools ===


=== International schools ===


=== Supplementary and extra schools ===
The Japanese Supplementary School of Phnom Penh , formerly known in English as the Phnom Penh Japanese School, is a part-time Japanese School, operated by the Japanese Association of Cambodia (JACAM;カンボジア日本人会 Kambojia Nihonjin-kai). It is in Sangkat Toek Thla in Sen Sok. It was established in 2002. It had 60 students in June 2011.


== Culture ==
Phnom Penh also has its own dialect of Khmer. Speakers of the Phnom Penh dialect often elide syllables, which has earned it the reputation for being lazy speech. Phnom Penh is also known for its influence on New Khmer Architecture. Phnom Penh is notable for Ka tieu Phnom Penh, its variation on rice noodle soup, a dish available in sit-down cafes as well as street cafes.
Music and the arts are making a revival throughout Cambodia, especially in Phnom Penh. Phnom Penh currently hosts a number of music events throughout the city. 'Indie' bands (those without corporate sponsors) have grown in number due also in part to the emergence of private music schools such as SoundsKool Music (also operating in the city of Siem Reap), and Music Arts School (registered as an NGO).
The two most visited museums in the city are the National Museum, which is the country's leading historical and archaeological museum, and Tuol Sleng Genocide Museum, a former Khmer Rouge prison. The National Museum hosts celebrations of Cambodian dance and music, including a popular classic Apsara dance show of traditional folk dances as well as original creations.
Chaul Chnam Thmey April 13–15

At this time, Phnom Penh celebrates Cambodian New Year, an occasion increasingly popular with tourists. During this typically hottest part of the year, water gets thrown around adding to the party atmosphere along with dancing and music. The precise date changes year-by-year but this holiday lasts, at least, three days. This festival marks the turn of the year based on the ancient Khmer calendar and also marks the end of the prior year harvest.
Water Festival November

The largest annual festival in Phnom Penh, this lively gathering celebrates the reversing of the flow of the Tonlé Sap River. The holiday lasts three days as people flood into the city to enjoy the fireworks, boat races, live concerts, eating and partying. The boat racing dates back to ancient times marking the strengths of the Khmer marine forces during the Khmer Empire.
On 22 November 2010 at least 348 people were crushed to death in a bridge stampede at the festival.Pchum Ben October 11–15 (2012)
Pchum Ben is a very important aspect of Cambodian culture. It may be translated as "gathering together" to make offerings and is a time of reunion, commemoration, express love and appreciation for one's ancestors. By offering food and good karma to those possibly trapped in the spirit world, living relatives help assuage their misery and guide them back into the cycle of reincarnation.
Visak Bochea May

Vesākha is an annual holiday observed traditionally by Buddhists in Cambodia. Sometimes informally called "Buddha's Birthday", it actually encompasses the birth, enlightenment (nirvāṇa), and passing away (Parinirvāna) of Gautama Buddha.


== Cityscape and architecture ==

The oldest structure is Wat Phnom from the founding days of the city, constructed in 1373. The main tourist attractions are the Royal Palace with the Silver Pagoda, and the National Museum, constructed during the French colonial era in the late-19th century in the classical Khmer style and hosting a vast collection of Khmer antiquities. The Independence Monument (Khmer: Vimean Akareach), although from the 1950s, is also constructed in the ancient Khmer style.
The French, who were the colonial masters from the 19th century to the 1940s, also left their mark, with various colonial villas, French churches, boulevards, and the Art Deco market Phsar Thom Thmei. A notable landmark of the colonial era is the Hotel Le Royal.

Starting with independence from the French in the 1950s and lasting until the era of the Khmer Rouge in the 1970s, Phnom Penh underwent tremendous growth as the capital city of a newly independent country. King Sihanouk was eager to present a new style of architecture and thus invigorate the process of nation building. A new golden era of architecture took off, with various projects and young Khmer architects, often educated in France, given opportunities to design and construct. This new movement was called "New Khmer Architecture" and was often characterised by a fusion of Bauhaus, European post-modern architecture, and traditional elements from Angkor. The most prominent architect was Vann Molyvann, who was nominated chief national architect by the king himself in 1956. Molyvann created landmark buildings such as the Preah Suramarit National Theatre and the Council of Ministers building. Other architects helped construct the newly founded Royal Khmer University, the Institute of Foreign Languages, and the National Sports Centre. With the growth of the upper and entrepreneurial middle classes, new suburbs were built in the 1950s and 1960s. Although these buildings survived the Khmer Rouge era and the civil war, today they are under threat due to economic development and financial speculation. Villas and gardens from that era are being destroyed and redeveloped to make place for bigger structures. The landmark National Theatre by Molyvann was razed in 2008. A movement is rising in Cambodia to preserve this modernist heritage. Old villas are sometimes being converted into boutique hotels, such as the Knai Bang Chatt. 
Monuments and memorials to the genocide of the Khmer Rouge era in the 1970s are the Tuol Sleng Genocide Museum (a former high school used as a concentration camp) and, on the outskirts of the city, the Choeung Ek Genocide Center. The Cambodia-Vietnam Friendship Monument was commissioned by the Vietnamese communists as symbol of Khmer-Vietnamese friendship during the late-1970s following the liberation of Cambodia from the Khmer Rouge.
The population, foreign investment, and urban development in Phnom Penh grew dramatically during the 1990s and early-2000s. The rapid growth resulted in the city's infrastructure distinctly lacking (the drainage system is particularly notorious, and Phnom Penh frequently floods during the wet season), and a need for both residential and commercial spaces. The simultaneous demand for residential and commercial housing and the increase of international investment has led to the planning, if not construction, of several satellite cities. The largest of these cities are: Grand Phnom Penh International City, CamKo City, Diamond Island City, Boeung Kak Town, and Chruy Cangva City.
On the outskirts of the city, farmland has been developed into garment factories and housing for lower economic classes and those displaced by the new development in the city center.


=== 2035 master plan ===
Originally intended to be completed by 2020, the 2035 master plan is a French-funded project for the development of Phnom Penh. Although the plan was approved by the Ministry of Land Management, Urban Planning and Construction in 2005, it has yet to be ratified by the Cabinet of Cambodia. The original plan details five edge-city projects connected to the historical city centre by waterways and tree-lined corridors.


== Media ==


=== Dailies ===


==== Khmer ====
Sralagn' Khmer (Love Khmer)
Chakraval Daily (Universe)
Kampuchea Thmei Daily (New Cambodia)
Kampuchea Tgnai Nis (Cambodia Today)
Kanychok Sangkhum (Social Reflection)
Koh Santepheap (Island of Peace)
Moneaksekar Khmer (Khmer Conscience) – Published by the Sam Rainsy Party.
Rasmei Kampuchea (Light of Kampuchea) – Cambodia's largest daily, it circulates about 18,000 copies.
Samleng Yuvachun (Voice of Khmer Youth)
Udomkate Khmer (Khmer Ideal)
Wat Phnom Daily (Mount Temple)


==== English ====
Phnom Penh Post, a daily English-language newspaper published in Phnom Penh.
The Cambodia Daily, an English-language daily newspaper (closed in 2017).
The Khmer Times, an English-language daily newspaper.


==== Chinese ====
《柬華日報》(Jianhua Daily), a daily Chinese-language newspaper published in Phnom Penh.
《星洲日報》(Sin Chew Daily), a Chinese-language daily newspaper, the Cambodian edition of the Malaysian Chinese daily of the same name.
《華商日報》(Huashang Daily), a Chinese-language daily newspaper.
《高棉日报》(Khmer Daily), a Chinese-language daily newspaper.
《新柬埔寨》(New Cambodia), a Chinese-language daily newspaper.


=== Magazines ===
AsiaLIFE Guide Phnom Penh, a monthly English-language lifestyle magazine published in Phnom Penh.
Pocket Guide Cambodia publishes four separate guides aimed at English-speaking residents and visitors.
F Magazine, the first fashion-forward magazine in Cambodia. Bi-lingual, written in English and Khmer.
SOVRIN Magazine, is the premium fashion magazine in Cambodia which written in khmer language.


=== Online news ===
Thmey Thmey Online News Phnom Penh.
Sabay News Phnom Penh.
Fresh News Phnom Penh


== Sport ==

The martial arts of Bokator, Pradal Serey (Khmer kick boxing) and Khmer traditional wrestling have venues in Phnom Penh watched by dedicated spectators. Cambodia has increasingly become involved in modern sports over the last 30 years. As with the rest of the country, football and the martial arts are particularly popular.  Ultimate fighting and freestyle boxing have also become more common in recent years.The most prominent sporting venue in the city is the Phnom Penh National Olympic Stadium with a capacity of 80,000—although the country never hosted the Olympic Games due to disruption by the civil war and the Khmer Rouge in the 1970s. Built in 1964, it is home to the Cambodian national football team. On completion the stadium was one of the largest in Asia. Today it is the 6th largest stadium in Southeast Asia. Volleyball, basketball, and Tai-Kwon-Do games are often hosted at the stadium.  The stadium closed in 2000, but was redeveloped and reopened.
The National Sports Centre of Cambodia hosts swimming, boxing, and volleyball competitions. Noted local football clubs include Phnom Penh Empire, Khemara Keila FC and Military Police.


== Transport ==

Phnom Penh International Airport is the largest and busiest airport in Cambodia. It is seven kilometres west of central Phnom Penh. The airport is connected to the city center by taxi, train, and shuttle bus.
Cambodia's national flag carrier, Cambodia Angkor Air, launched in 2009, is headquartered in Phnom Penh and has its main hub there, with an additional hub at the Angkor International Airport.Air France used to serve Phnom Penh from Paris-Charles de Gaulle but this service has since stopped. Qatar Airways now flies to and from Phnom Penh, via Ho Chi Minh City.
Taxis, pick-ups, and minibuses leave the city for destinations all over the country, but are fast losing ground to cheaper and more comfortable buses. Phnom Penh also has a rail service.
There are numerous bus companies, including Phnom Penh Public Transport and GST Express, running services to most provincial capitals, including Sihanoukville, Kampong Chhnang, Oudong and Takéo. Phnom Penh Sorya Transport Co. offers bus service to several provincial destinations along the National Routes and to Ho Chi Minh City. Giant Ibis is another bus company based in Phnom Penh, which travels to Sihanoukville, Kampot, Siem Reap and Ho Chi Minh, and has free Wi-Fi, air conditioning and modest pricing.
The city is Cambodia's main freshwater port, a major port on the Mekong River. It is linked to the South China Sea, 290 kilometres distant, via a channel of the Mekong in Vietnam.


=== Public transport ===

Phnom Penh is served by three air conditioned bus lines. Initial attempts by the Japanese government to develop a Phnom Penh bus service began in 2001. An update of the JICA urban transport master plan for Phnom Penh was completed and implemented in 2014. The city is now served by three bus lines, operated by the Phnom Penh municipal government. Private transportation within the city include the cycle rickshaw, known in Khmer as "cyclo", the motorcycle taxi known in Khmer as "moto", the auto rickshaw known locally as "tuk-tuk", the trailer attached to a motorcycle taxi known in Khmer as "remorque", and the standard automobile taxicab known in Khmer as "taxi". Private forms of transportation used by locals include bicycles, motorbikes, and cars.


=== Highways ===

As the capital of Cambodia, a number of national highways connect the city with various parts of the country:


== Water supply ==

Water supply in Phnom Penh has improved dramatically in terms of access, service quality, efficiency, cost recovery and governance between 1993 and 2006. The number of customers has increased ninefold, service quality has improved from intermittent to continuous supply, water losses have been cut dramatically and the city's water utility went from being bankrupt to making a modest profit. These achievements were recognized through international awards such as the 2006 Ramon Magsaysay Award and the 2010 Stockholm Industry Water Award. The city's water utility is the Phnom Penh Water Supply Authority (PPWSA). Its main water sources are the Mekong River, the Tonle Sap river and the Tonle Bassac river.

text.quote: Buddhist temple built on site of 14th-century pagoda & at 27 m, tallest religious structure in city.
trip: I visited because it was close to the hostel we stayed at but it was a really great surprise really historical importance to the city

It was built in 1373, and stands 27 meters above the ground. It is the tallest religious structure in the city. Said to be built by a lady who came from Angkor areas with help of few others and with that city Phnom Penh came into existence. It has lot of significance for local
It was an enjoyable relaxing place to spend an afternoon. The temple is quiet small but the gardens surrounding it ar very nice. Worth a visit if youre in Phnom Penh.
The temple is quite a climb up to the highest point in PP at 89 meters. But the grounds and buildings are beautiful. The view is pretty much blocked by huge trees surrounding the Wat.
Loved it and got t all to ourselves the flowers were just lovely and the naga snake was very cool worth stopping by

This is traditionally where the city of Phnom Penh was founded. The temple here is not the oldest one can see, but it is rich with murals, some of the best I have seen. One can see rituals outside on the patio around the temple. The setting is beautiful, though a high spot there

It is set on the highest point in the city at 89 feet. Quite a few steps to climb to the top but worth the effort. There is a shrine to Duan Penh behind the sanctuary. She was the one who found the Buddha statues on the shores of the Tonle Sap River and laid the foundations for

At the top of a long flight of stairs sits a modest temple that is very important to the people of Phnom Penh. Named after a woman who helped found the city at this point. Some very elaborate statues and paraphernalia inside. A group of musicians was playing while we were there
Very beautiful, but there was not a lot of information on this particular religious site. You could walk around and look at all the spires and animals living nearby.

A lovely temple perched on a hill in the middle of the city. For the $1-2 it is to get in well worth the visit. There are quite a number of stairs to get to the top but well worth it. We would definitely recommend.

A single dollar entry if you are not a local. A very old temple right in the centre of Phnom Penh. The inside is beautiful as they all are. As soon as we arrived, we paid another $3 so I could set three birds free from a cage. Poor things. Don’t miss the garden clock on ground
I am pleased I visited here as the architecture is most impressive and the whole area is pleasant and tranquil. No need to spend a long time here but should be visited.

We visited here on our way to the Royal Palace and for $1.00 entry, it is worthwhile seeing. The architecture is lovely and although perhaps we didn’t fully appreciate the religion and stories behind this place, it was still magnificent to see. Would recommend if in Phnom Penh.
Lovely and clean temples I love the pictures that tell a story in walls. Lovely bit of Cambodia. There are two different buildings.

Interesting place. I do think that the outside is more interesting of the inside and like very much the manicured gardens that lead to the temple. Has there isn’t much to see in Phnom Penh this is...it!

Wat Phnom is a Buddhist temple located in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. It was built in 1372, and stands 27 metres above the ground. It is the tallest religious structure in the city. At the lower Temple you can observe devoutees offering gifts to Budda. There is a higher level and its

Don’t hurry, take your time to soak in some quiet spirit and witness the Locals paying homage to Lady Penh. Steps to temple are not that challenging as there are not so many compared to other temples. Note the statue of Lady Penh in the temple, she is in blue with botox-like

We visited Wat Phnom at night and thought it was nice, but expected to spend more time here. They let us in after hours for the posted price of 1 USD and it is a nice temple, but we thought the most exciting thing about this activity was the giant bats flying around. That being

An active temple, it reveals itself not only its historical role in naming of the city, but also its active role as a temple with Cambodian smart phone toting musicians, but also attendees who leave offerings and bustle around the side temples. Some come to sightsee. Others

We were taken here as part of a full day PP tour and it was very interesting. It was a holy day with musicians playing loudly - fortunately finishing just after we arrived! Our guide Prakob provided great information on the Buddhist rituals, making the visit even more special

One one hand there isn't a lot to see in Phnom Penh - seriously - after 4 or 5 days you will be running out of places to visit - so a visit to Wat Phnom is always on the cards. It is worth seeing but it cowers in respect to places such as Angkor Wat. Nevertheless it is worth

We traveled there at 29th December 2019. The southwest corner of the temple and stupa, is a small shrine dedicated to Lady Penh (Also Know as Grandmother Penh). The front is often crowded with the faithful bringing their prayers and food offerings to the woman deemed responsible

In Phnom Penh you're going to visit this Wat. The Wat itself is impressive in its decoration. Set on a small hill, it has an interesting history and, at the time of our visit, was visited by the Cambodian Transportation minister (plus wife and numerous bodyguards!) who was
Small hill with a temple up top. Nothing special but worth a visit. We went there as a group and received a blessing.

The hill gives its name to the city . It’s a place where you come and make wishes for luck . It’s a bit a a circus but if you get there early is ok .Its impressive and worth seeing on tour of the city .
Not as good as hoped for. Quite impressive from a distance but not a massive amount to look at once you have climbed the stairs. USD 1 entry fee for foreigners.

Cross over the bridge that used to span a canal and you are in front of the floral clock at the base of the hill that is surmounted by the temple. Climb up the steps to get a closer look a this historic structure. Don't feed the monkeys, they sometimes bite.
Probably just need no more than an hour to visit here. It is quiet and the grounds are kept fairly clean. There are a few vendors selling food and drinks on the outside. No admission fee.
Beautiful temple that is still used. Plenty of incense and food used in offerings. $1 at the gate for foreigners. Just be respectful and remove shoes when others do and your fine.
We accidentally stumbled upon this and didn’t pay (unintentionally) again fairly ordinary and the $1 seems opportunistic. Can get some good views from the boundary if you don’t want to pay.
Not a bad temple to have a look at if in area. Only 1usd to get in but looks like you can easily sneak in. No dress code enforced. Nice for a walk around and photos

This is the titular and anthropological heart of the City so it's a must to visit. The nagas greet the guest at the foot of the hill and then there are the Boddhisatva statues at the top of it and to the side of the main temple, representing as they do various stages of Buddhist

I loved visiting this temple, quite steep steps, but you can walk around a ramped path way. Beautiful decor and statues. There was music and chanting, you can light incense and pray. Take your shoes off at the front door, but to get them back, you have to pay a couple of

It's a nice place to relax, as the temple has a nice park around it. The temple is open until 18:00. Make sure that you are in appropriate clothing - shoulders and knees are covered. There is a large kids playground next to the park. The post office colonial style building is a
Lovely Wat in the centre of Phnom Penh, which our group visited after visiting the Royal Palace complex. Rather compact with a lot to see and well worth the visit.
Visited here with our guide a really beautiful temple and we had the added benefit of being blessed by a monk which was very special

This is a very old Wat in Phnom Penh City,and the city was named after it. Check on the historical aspect reveals that a wealthy widow called Penh constructed a small shrine on an artificial hill to protect four bronze statues of the Buddha. The artificial hill is now the
Wat Phnom it is stupa of Khmer King from 14 th it was very good to visiting that is a lot local people coming to praying and Visiting this place .
Great stop to phnom had a great experience of learning different culture. Highly recommend this place to visit

According to inscription at the site legend has it, that this hill was built artificially on instruction of a wealthy widow who found a Buddha statue in a floating bark on the river. A small shrine was built on the top to house the statue. Climbing the stairs surrounded by trees
There's not much unique about this temple but join the local crowds and make an offering. You never know what luck or grace may come of it.

This is a great stop on your visit to Phnom Penh. You learn here that this is where the city gets its name, how the hill was built with the nearby villagers, and the inside is beautiful with many Buddha’s and a wonderful painter ceiling. All of this for 1 USD. We were there
Even though in the city it is peaceful. Inside, the temple is beautiful. The grounds around are well maintained with many little shrines. I was interested in the shrine with flashing lights.

Date of Visit : 23 Dec 2019 After breakfast, we were supposed to “stroll” here, then it got warmer and warmer, so we cooled down and recharged at Exchange Square before adjourning here. Took several pictures of Wat Phnom, Statue of Yeay Penh and also an impressive government
There is an ambience there, and the position on the hill is lovely. Wonderful old trees surround it. But the murals and the feeling inside are magic. Recommended.

It's one of the places in the city that worth to visit. There's a temple at the top where the religious people can visit. I like the place around where you can just sit and relax especially when it's too warm in the city.
In the day you can go up to see this temple for just one dollar. The gardens are peaceful and relaxing despite being in the centre of town. Best viewed though at night where it glows gold.

A small but very old Wat after which the city was named. On an artificial hill which is now the centre of a big roundabout. Some lovely old trees and a real feeling of calm about the place. Worth a visit.

Apart from the usual 'must-go' such as CE, S21 and Royal Palace, this is something for a less hectic schedule. Ticket is only 1USD for foreigners and there is a small park to spend a few hrs at. Some sights around the park include a huge clock (reminiscent of the one in
For me the place was interesting,maybe because the group was lead by a very good guide who told us the legend,the importance of the hill and pagoda for the city .
Little buddhist temple off the beaten track, more authentic than the Royal Palace (and silver pagoda). Absolutely worth visiting.
A visit after sunset is definitely recommened but the temple is open only till 6 pm. The interior of budhha temple is beautiful

It was recommended to visit in the the early evening and I was very happy to get this advice. It was much cooler and quiet. The pagoda isnt very big but the grounds around were very nice to walk around. It was peaceful and only cost $1.

Stayed locally and crossed the road into the memorial park and Wat Phnom. We paid $1 each to enter the grounds at night. The lighting against the architecture was stunning. Best viewed in my opinion at night to get the real feel for the temple and grounds. I would advice going
A small hill crowned by an active wat (pagoda) marks the legend of Phnom Penh City. As a tourist they have a USD 1 entrance fee.

We went to this place because the Palace was closed without any notice until 2:30, so we spend some time here.... Do you have to come here.... not really.... does it worth you time... perhaps not, but we had nothing to do until the Palace reopen at 2:30

I visited the Temple during the day and there is a $1 entry fee for foreigners. There are a few steps to climb and the Temple is a peaceful oasis amongst the busy and noisy city. There are some nice flower borders around the Temple and it was a quiet and calming place to spend

Nice full story on this one. Not really elaborate on the outside but on the inside wow. Have local musicians playing a lot of people come here to workshop and the food displays are amazing that are given as offerings.

We visited Wat Phnom with a local guide who was able to provide us with useful information on the shrine. It's the highest point in the city and although not a huge amount to see it is very colourful and worth a visit.
Hill Monument of the capital with pagode and stupa. Statue of Don Penh as the mother of the town. Place for resting and viewing with interesting trees and wishes.

Historically more significant than it is to look at, this Pagoda will not detain you long but it is still worth a look if you are in the area. At 27 meters high ontop of a man made Hill, it is the tallest religious structure in Phnom Penn and is worth a look for the interior
As previously mentioned allow about 15 minutes as it's just another temple ... but it does have painted ceilings? that were perhaps done for tourists.

I know cambodia is full of temples and its easy to say 'its just another temple" however I quite enjoyed looking round here and at a cost of 1 dollar it is worth an hour of your time. I Particularly enjoyed watching local people praying and making offerings.

Wat Phnom is a Buddha temple on man-made hill of about 100 feet height. Can see the tall Buddha statue inside the temple with bright modern murals depicting the lives of the Buddha and other stories. Can see people offer prayers here. The temple hill is surrounded by a huge
You don't need to allow too much time here. Probably far more impressive at night when lit up. Spent about 15 minutes here.

Very central you can’t miss it A pagoda on the top of an artificial 28 meter high hill. Around the hill are gardens The pagoda nothing spectacular just go to spend a 30 mins if there is nothing else to do. Tickets are 1 dollar for foreigners
Wat Phnom is history of Phnom Penh capital. Nice to understand. There is khmer temple and Chinese temple with nice park. Entry one dollar.

A nice spot in Phnom Penh. $1 per person to go inside, so good value. The wat itself is nicely kept and usually there is incense lit inside. Shoes must be taken off before going inside of course. If you have an hour or two to kill in Phnom Penh and want to have a little bit of
Nice garden and temple, as a foreigner you need to pay $1 or 4000 Riem. It is the Wat that gave the city its name! Worth a visit! A place full of history with 700y
Culturally significant and important to the history of Phnom Penh but not the most magnificent temple in Cambodia. Worth a visit
Visited as a group. Very interesting. Great to have a guided tour as we needed the explanation Make sure you visit here when in this city

Wat Phnom is a must see for travelers to Phnom Penh. Filled with traditional customs, locals make a daily pilgrimage to bask in the radiance of their gods. On special holidays, the City organizes events such as musical bands, water events and a local favourite, games with
Quiet nice during the evening , quiet and a lot less people , only 1 dollar entrance to see a little green space in the middle of PP.
Small Temple on a Hill that's all it is. $2 ticket for foreigners. Is it worth seeing? Notat alli feel that the square that's next to it is much more interesting
If you are in Phnom Penh you should visit this nice Wat. Shaded paths surround it. They charge foreigners $1 to visit.
We paid $1 each to enter. It was closed and local people were able to walked around the back and entered.
A very nice temple and the surroundings. Easy accessible and easy to find in a big roundabout. A place to relax in the shade of the beautiful trees.

Buddhist Temple, walking distance from Mekong River, in beautiful gardens located in the French Quarter of Phnom Penh. It costs $1 for a ticket to enter and is well worth the climb up stairs to the main Temple with views over the gardens with huge garden clock.
We walked around there by night. The Temples were closed. Only Foreigners pay 1US$ to get in. I should have made a photo of the sign.

Spend few days in Phnom Penh. I also visited Wat Phnom where is history of Phnom Penh city. it was grate to visit the temple on the top of mountain. Entry fee just 1 USD. Should visit Wat Phnom as you are in Phnom Penh.

Located on top of a small tree covered hill, 27 mts high,in the city center, it costs $1 to enter. Quite a few steps to reach the temple at the top. Built in 1372, and is the tallest religiuos structure in the city. Pleasant walks around the hill, as its well shaded. Look out

One dollar entrance fee brings you up the stairs to a small but peaceful, beautiful temple. Remove your shoes and enjoy. Lovely descending walkway back to the bottom. After you see several temples they all tend to blend together and feel the same.
A lovely temple on a hill surrounded by lovely grounds which were very pleasant to walk around in the early evening.

Not much to this Temple. A fairly short climb up & there are a series of different levels around the Temple. There is some nice trees & plants around the site & it’s very worthwhile walking around the entire site at ground level to get a different perspective.
OK, if you have nothing to do. There isnt much to do in Phnom Penh for tourists. Shopping, eating and drinking.

I would recommend visiting the temple when in Phnom Penh. For multiple reasons including the fact that this place could be a good area for some relaxation besides just exploring the architecture and arts.
Very nice place slightly outside the main downtown area. Small entrance fee of $1-$2 (I forget exactly how much) so if already in the area then worth the stop!

Our initial thought was that Wat Phnom was distant apart. However, given it was too close to our Hotel, we were happy to visit this first. Amongst various options, this is worth a visit especially for the arrangements inside. A calm, relaxing place.
Really enjoyed my visit here after arriving in the afternoon. I went about 4:30, and it was nice and relaxed, with not many people there. Only $1 to get in.
good temple to visit. entry for foriegn national 1$. surrounding the temple there is small children park
Temple is made out of cement and not really interesting or good looking. I don't see how this adds to any visit to Phnom Penh.

This is an interesting temple to visit in pretty much the centre of Phnom Penh. It has an impressive entrance and any foreigner can climb the elaborate steps for $1. We visited this without a guide and we went round in about half an hour, it would be difficult to spend longer

Legendary site of the foundation of Phnom Penh, but now on a roundabout. Free to Cambodians, but visitors should pay the small entrance fee at the booth in front of the steps. Very atmospheric temple at top.
I enjoyed our visit here and didn’t find the hawkers to be a problem as others suggest. A vey calm and contemplative environment.

Wat Phnom is nice for a quick visit and a walk around the gardens, but you will not need to spend longer than 1 hour here as there isn’t a great deal to see. But it is only $1usd to enter so it is nice for a half day visit if you are in the area.

Nothing much , just a temple on the manmade elevated hill , just a 20mns tour is enough We rented a tuk tuk for all location for a day for 25 $ from 8am to 3pm We covered killing field, Russian market , s21 , lunch near river , wat phnom and lastly at kings palace dropped

This was our first thing we visited in our Phnom Penh tour. A pretty temple on a small hill in homage to Lady Penh. Worth a stop off and the explanation from our guide as to the history of the site and what was going on made it worthwhile.
A nice quick stopping point around town. Nice peaceful location with a large natural clock at the base.
Beautiful temple located on the top of the hill . The color pallet inside is stunning . Definitely visit it !

A peaceful temple close to the centre hub of the city. Foreigners are charged $1 entry which is for nothing. I spent 25-30 minutes here it’s worth a trip if you have an hour to kill. TUK TUK drovers outside are the only problem as usual in Phnom Penh
Tranquil grounds at the temple. The city might be 100m away, but this felt a serene and peaceful venue. No hawkers within the Wat contributed. Worth the dollar entry.
This is a small hill for worship that can be visited by tourists (so dress appropriately). There is small entrance fee.

It a nice place to visit. Surprised to see vendors selling currency for exchange in millions.The place is filled with Fruit vendors/painting and art vendors. One of the finest tender coconuts are available for satisfying the thirst. It is a phenomenal place. All the temples in
Beautiful sacred place. Do not wear short shorts/dress , sleeveless And/or too much skin clothes if you want to enter inside pagoda
worth a stroll around during the day when it's not too hot. Picturesque wat atop a hill in the city centre
Interesting Wat on TOP of a small hill. Not the biggest or ‘best’ but very worthwhile to walk around and absorb local life, in particular on weekend.

Well I have nothing much to say about this place..The only reason I visited this place is to see the large clock at the garden....=) But it is a relaxing place to visit when the sun is going down (around 5pm+) If you want to see the temple at the top, there will be some

If you visit Phnom Penh then the Wat Phnom is definitely one of the main points of interest. You can see a pagoda with an impressive stair up the hill and take the time and walk around the hill - see the traffic around it, the US embassy (has a little bit the same history then

Wat Phnom is centrally located in Phnom Penh. That is the symbol of the capital city of Phnom Penh, was built on an artificial 88.5 ft (27 meter) hill (or 'Phnom') closed to Tonle Sap river. It’s an historical place that it’s must visit when you come to Phnom Penh. I would

This was a cool little find. The entry was 1 dollar per person and I think that only applies to foreigners. The temple at the top of the steps was really beautiful, and had a few people playing music while we were there. The giant clock was also pretty cool!
We come this place for visiting around City tour. This stupa of Khmer king and for tickets is 1usd...
The outside may look like any other wat but the interior is beautiful. And the grounds are nice to walk around too. The giant clock is unique. Worth a visit.

Standing on a small hill, this temple of Lord Buddha is quite attractive. Inside is a large seated bronze statue of lord Buddha . The murals showing scenes from the Ramayana and Jataka tales is worth seeing. The main stairway leading to the temple is lined with statues and

Outside of weekends, Wat Phnom is a pleasant place to visit. The elephant and monkeys of yesteryear have gone, but the trees - which provide ample shade - and the monuments are here to allow you to spend an agreeable morning or afternoon (I recommend the morning for more quiet).
I saw this as a must visit place in Phnom Penh and did not find this place that attractive or great. Just visit this place if want to kill some time and keep your expectations very low.
I dont get that much good to see the view of it. Rather i will suggest you to go other places if you are in hurry. they also take 1 usd as entry fees.
While walking around central Phnom Penh I visited this wat A tranquil area in a very busy city Beutiful building and quiet gardens
Lovely place to walk around amd escape the heat. $1 admission. Beautiful architecture and gardens. Spent 30min there wouldn't need much longer

The Buddha temple is on a small hill, some 27 meters high. It has an idol of Lady Penh, the woman who found a log of wood with 5 idols, 4 of Buddha and 1 of Lord Vishnu. The place is very quaint and has a large clock, a great spot for pics.

Being right in the middle of Phnom Penh this is an easy Wat to visit with lots of steps for your daily exercise. Good views are in short supply but the beautiful golden Buddha is worth the effort. Very impactfully, there is a tree at the bottom of the steps on the opposite

Located at the north end of Norodom boulevard. An impressive Stupa sits atop of the small hill, (just a bump really)there’s a quaint story of how the site was founded, be sure check it out... If you’re lucky you’ll see wild monkeys, failing that there are still other
It costs $1 to enter. You can take pictures. Sit down and observe people coming to pray. It is on a small hill not much city view though.

Nice. but it lacks of good views. But overall it’s fine. It’s only 1$ entrance. So nothing to complain about.

Interesting site, although bit annoying they only charge foreigners for entry, but itis cheap enough though and worth a visit to see it. Also you can time it right and go to the night market at the same time.
This monestary is very beautiful. The Lord budhha is looking very beautiful inside the monestary. You can pray there for hours. Must visit. Om Mani padme hun.
Great location to start explore the city and its origin. Hilltop with a temple and opportunity to go around and explore

It is located next to US Embassy. $1 entrance fee for foreigners only. There are some people selling survenir and other goods around the temple. You climb up stairs to reach the small temple. 15 min is enough to see everything, so if you are in the area, it is nice to visit.
Easy to get to if you are out and about in Phnom Phen though the temple itself is fairly standard. It does have some really nice items on show in cases here though. There is s cost to enter here too

We visited when the Khmer New Year was happening. During the day the place was made up with the most beautiful decorations. Lots of markets, 2 live music stages and lots of people dancing. Families and friends celebrating and having a great time! We went back in the evening and
The place where the capital city start it's an historical temple of daun Penh. It's must visit when you come to Phnom Penh.
This temple was amazing and the people who tend this place do so with so much care and consideration. Loved the visit and even had a meditation while I was there found it very uplifting.

Was there during Khmer New Year 2019. Some major attractions of the city were closed because of Cambodian New Year. Sad about that I went to Wat Phnom - and I think almost everyone was here. So many people, music, picnic, street food, small stages, singing, dancing the whole
Tourist attractions in Phnom Penh are few and far between. Wat Phnom is one of the major ones. Visit will be short takes around 15m
Great temple and guide with ample history of there blessing to the lady of the house. If you have difficult with steps there is 86 to reach the temple.

Wat Phnom is a quick and easy tourist attraction to visit. It’s $1 usd to enter and takes about 15-30mins to see depending on how fast you want to get through it. Take slip on shoes so you take take them on and off easily to enter the temple at the top. Also, be prepared to
A large well managed pagoda area. Nice environment and with a little walk of stairs you can have good views to various directions. It is just a couple of minutes walk from the riverside.
Another great place to visit whilst in the city they were preparing for their kama New Year when we were there so lots of activity and excitement added to the atmosphere of the place

After paying a dollar you get to go up the steps, look in the temple and come back down again. You only need about 10 minutes and whilst it is a nice temple, there was nothing particularly amazing about it, nor was the view particularly good as trees block most of it out.
We went here as it was on the list of top things to do, however, it is a small temple on a hill in the middle of a traffic circle. Nothing special about it except the clock.

I have been to Wat Phnom twice but the most fun was the most recent New Year's Day Celebrations. There was a lot of activity, dancing, live bands, lots of talcum powder and a showering of water from the fire trucks that kept all the revelers comfortable.
Small park with alot of trees and green grasses... its nice place to take a break from busy town and go for a walk.. also alot of monkeys in the park and should be careful with your belongings
Went during the new year celebration. So was a huge party with dancing/ music and large crowds. Felt safe whilst busy. The temple at the top was beautiful.

Paid our dollar and asked if we were dressed okay as my husbands shorts didn't quite cover his knees but we were told that this was fine. Lovely entrance and gardens around the temple and a nice place to just wander around,

There is a booth outside the temple and i think foreigners need to pay a fee to visit. Walk up a flight of stairs and you will reach the temple. Not stroller/wheelchair friendly. Shoes must be removed to enter the temple.

Very sacred place and well visited by both locals and foreign guest. Paid one USD the went to a special funds so well worth. The temple up the hill was well preserved and I enjoyed the short walk u OK the hill and it was such a peacefully environment. Will go back again soon
Good cultural experience definitely worth visiting when you are in Phnom Penh.. you will get to know the cultural significance and how the culture evolved..

I was here 6 years ago and we visited Wat Phnom.I remembered it as being a smaller area and not half as well maintained as it is now.It was walking distance from our hotel so we just walked up the road.Foreigners pay a nominal amount to get in.Many locals were out and about

Cheap to enter and yet I was still disappointed. The grounds are well kept but the inside of the temple is dingy and forgettable - so much so that I had to check my photos to remind myself of what it looked like, and I was there less than a week ago.
Wat Phnom is probably not everybody's go, but is a very important historical site for the Cambodian culture. Even if only a brief visit, you should make the effort.

We had a full day tour and Wat Phnom was our last stop in the afternoon. It was not that busy and also cooler than mid-day. It is not a big place but very interesting history and a tour guide really helps. Worth a stop.
The actual Wat is very interesting to see. The area around it is also very nice & a good place to chill. There are plenty of eateries & street food surrounding it. Worth a look if you are passing by.

Really, it us quite exquisite in the day, or lit up at night (though the grounds get locked up at night). Truly just something you should see if you go to Phnom Pehn. You can drive by it in a tuk tuk and miss the wonderment, so get out and spend a half hour to hour to stroll

One of the major landmarks of Phnom Penh. Check out for a number of ceremonies held inside the Pagoda. Wat Phnom is used as a rendezvous by many visitors. While entry is free for locals, foreigners are charged 4000 Riels. It is better not to buy anything here as the prices are

The historical landmark of phnom penh city. Very nice place to see for city tour kaa. A lot of big tree make the atmosphare so chill. On the top of mountain have khmer pagoda and nrct there have chinese pagoda. This place local people strongly believe in. You need to try one day

A truly gorgeous temple which is a must see. It only costs $1 to get in. A few steps to climb which is hard in the sun but worth it. You can go into the temple at the top, which is very ornate and leave offerings to their Buddha if you believe.

This was one of our favorite temples in Cambodia. It is still in very good shape and is situated in a pleasant, park like setting that gives it a sense of peace amid the hustle and bustle of the surrounding city. Worth seeing.

This temple has s great storey . Across the square is a statue of lady Phenom who inspired the temple. At 1.usd this had a lovely park with a giant working clock , flower gardens and sculptures. The temple is small but peaceful a great place to sit against the wall and
A place where lots of tourists and local will visit, tourist will have to pay a visiting fee of USD 1 per person .

I liked this temple.it cost a dollar to get in.There were musicians in the temple playing traditional music (at 5pm) creating a great ambiance .Had a nice park surrounding it with lots of shade. It has a large flight of stairs so not for people with mobility issues.Only five

If you are a tourist, there's might not much to see here except the main temple area and the craft store. If you do not really check the craft store in detail, it might take 30 minutes to look around. On the weekend you will see a group of men practicing something that almost

up a little hill, much more gentrified now than when I visited many years ago.They now charge foreigner US$1 to go in. just a little temple on top a hill, reputedly the reason for the town of Phnom Penh being founded here. Lots of longan trees surrounding the temple so great in

This was a lovely little site and well worth the numerous steps up. It smelled great with all the incense burning too. Make you you walk through the grounds at the bottom and find the amazing craft gallery - really fabulous collection of Cambodian arts and crafts at a range of
Nice Park if you are walking around the city good place to come and relax and eat your lunch. I wouldn't pay to see it on a tour.

Worth a visit, especially for the history to the temple. There are sub-temples where people pray and while there is a fee to enter it is a small price to pay to ensure the temple is maintained. Worth a visit.
We visited as part of our tour itinerary and it was well worth visiting. Our guide was very good and I would recommend a visit here
For foreigners, we have to pay $1. You can walk around, climb up the stairs, and take pictures. Nothing much to do here.

Great spot to visit and well worth the $1. I would recommend this over the National Museum and Kings Palace. If you can, find a guide that can tell you a bit about the history, why it's named after Grandmother Penh etc.
