Evening time on the two adjoining "boulevards" where the 3 main monuments are situated is very special . There are aerobic (line dancing) classes, improvised soccer matches, food wagons and dining areas, people strolling/jogging and generally a nice communal atmosphere.

You cant miss this monument as it is a centerpiece along a popular road. There wasnt enough to make me want to stop and look at it in detail. I may be missing any historical reference but i didnt find it to be anything special.
Very large monument in the heart of the city, no need to make special trip here as you will probably pass it numerous times whilst exploring the city. Looks better at night when all lit up.
We had a nice stroll in the Independence Monument continued to the Friendship Monument on the way to the Royal Palace!

This is right in the centre of the city. And was built to celebrate the independence from the french. It is typically well lit and looks good at night. We can skip this, or just pass through siting in a cab..
Just a monument in a big avenue. It takes 10 minutes to see it and walk around by a pedestrians area special made to walk.

Passed the Independence monument and park a few times everyday as it was on the way to our accommodation, always nice to walk around there rather than on the side walks. In the evening, people do sport around there etc...
Very impressive monument in the center of the city. Hard to miss, since it is huge. In the evening it is more beautiful, as they light it up.
This monument sits in the middle of sihanouk blvd. Easy to access and free but not much to it and much more interesting things to visit.
An impressive monument in the middle of the road. Photos can be taken from the vehicle as you drive past. It's shame that it's not in a park where the visitor can pay proper homage to it.

It was built in the year 1958 to memorialize Cambodia’s independence from France in the year 1953. It stands on the intersection of boulevards in the centre of the city. The structure height is 20 metres or 66 feet. It is in the form of a lotus shaped stupa of Buddhist style.
located in plain sight of the city,nearbty the royal palace and indo china monument. visit early in the morning for a good photo shoot with not so many people

Our Tuk tuk driver was sailing past this monument so we tapped him on the shoulder to indicate we'd like to stop & take a look around. Quite an impressive sight & you can capture quite a vista in your photos if you allow a moment to see what is on offer . Looks great against the

just forget it! not worth a glance. to visit, you have to take a motobike or tuktuk on noisy polluted streets to see a big concrete monument in the center of a vast crossing of different large streets.
It's exactly like in the pics. Nothing much to it in my opinion. You could just drive around it on your way somewhere instead of stopping and getting down.
Majestic monument in the middle of busy traffic. Grab a Tuk Tuk and safely cruise around the center of town.
Definitely has a meaningful presence. Good for a photograph or two. It is in the middle of a roundabout though.

This is a lovely monument which you cannot miss. It is surrounded by busy roads on each far side. Close to the monument is a nice green space and a few chair benches to sit on. There are many tourist buses in the area so trying to get a photo can be a bit of a challenge

And boy did I take a lot of photos in front of this monument as well as from the side views. Prince Sihanouk's mid 60s folly still looks suitably grand and imposing. Besides, it is impossible to take a bad picture of it!
You can see the pictures if you really need to see it in person I doubt your reaction will be much different

I visited this during the day, right bang in the middle of a road, you can walk right up to the building, but most people were taking pictures from opposite road, lovely structure of a building, must see place, would recommend
We went to the killing fields and our tuktuk stopped here for some pictures. Nice statue on an impressive square.
Our visit their independence monument was basically a drive-by still it was beautiful from the van maybe you shouldn’t miss it
Finally a place to walk without being hassled by tuktuk or other sellers. Open clean space makes for great walks at any time of the day.
It's an impressive monument accompanied by a long garden where you can walk. It's quite lovely at night when lit up. Good place for a morning or evening stroll.
A great monument that is lit up at night. It's a shame that it is in the middle of a very busy roundabout so it's tough to just take it in without worrying about all the vehicles!

Open area surrounded by bustling traffic and very busy roundabout with a well lit monument to independence in the centre. We walked there at night and enjoyed the atmosphere and there are some good restaurants nearby as well as street food stalls.
A must see especially if you know the history of Cambodia. Easy to find and nice surrounds. Popular with the locals on Sundays
located at the heart of city, just take a tuk tuk and you can visit anytime. For taking photos better visit at evening time.

This monument ia interesting and picturesque, part of a cluster in central Phnom Penh. It is slightly difficult to get closer access to due to it being surrounded by a busy road network, which perhaps limits the visitors it gets.

It’s a landmark in the truest sense as it gives you a central place in the city. It’s useful if you have to direct a tuk tuk, or tell somebody where something is. It’s also pretty enough to see as you walk by, but that’s about it. It’s not easy to get to since it’s in the middle
An important landmark in Phnom Penh and a popular place for locals to exercise in the early morning or evening. Mornings will see exercise classes, aerobic groups and even some form of ti chi

We had a great time with beautiful eyes to visit this Independence Monument of Cambodia where the building built dedicate to whom devoted their lives for nation. And they are real compatriots for all of Cambodian remembrance.

This is an imposing tower built of dark red sandstone and sits in the middle of a large busy roundabout. You can’t get in as the exits are roped off. It is of local significance but to me it was just a big tower!
Wonderfull place . And worth seeing at night time . Makes much bigger impression that day time. Quite a central location in town.
We stopped part of the tour. Nice place, right in the middle of the city. Good to see the local kids/families there, and their lives.
This is symbol of Cambodia independence, nothing to see inside except to take a round of building. Good decoration and very clean lawn to sit in evening.
One of the landmarks of the capital Phnom Penh. Ideal for photography. The superb lighting changes the color of the monument. A must visit in the evening.

There is not much to this monument visit which is located at the centre of several roads leading to it. Best time to visit it is after dark at night when the monument is lit up. Suggestion is go for to boat cruise on Tonle Sap river (we took Kanika boat) and then stroll to the
The monument is pretty much in the middle of phnom penh and was around the corner of our hotel. It looks nice especialy lit up at night.
Yes its nice. And new. Everything around also very clean and nice. That‘s it. Nothing special, not a must see...

I was driven by it and thought it was beautiful, but I did not stop to see it being in the middle of a turnabout. Celebrates independence from France or at least that is what showed when my local friend used Google translate
Centrally located and well lit at night, shows the dates and other information of the terrible Khmer rouge rein
Its no more than a quick look at and a nice photo of this lovely monument , but that's to be expected
Take a walk around the square , at night or day, it's beautiful! Many people walk or jog along here throughout the day
A nice part with a lot of locals either running, playing or just sitting on the grass talking with friends! The monument is nice specially when is dark!
Worth coming to see in the day - although often swarmed over by buses of tour groups, but it is very pretty at night when it is all lit up
Its a monument in the middle of a roundabout. Either take a look from your tuk tuk as you drive around or get out to take a photo.......simples 👍
The monument stays in the middle of roundabout, so you can not come near. It looks very simple, but nice.
Very grand looking at night with lighting at the present time in the surrounding trees. You can't miss it as it's quite massive

We've passed through the monument several times but it looks better at night. The design is great but as it is placed in the round-about, it is quite difficult to stay and take pictures especially when the traffic flow is heavy. It's a monument that carries great symbol and

We did a quick stop here at the monument and took some photos. We are unsure of the history around this but we think it symbolic of the freedom from 100 years of French colonialism. There is a picture of the former president beside the monument but it had the wrong dates as says

Symbolic great value, and the design is nice. It is a landmark for Phnom Penh but can easily be skipped. During the day the traffic is just insane as is the pollution. The building and surrounding areas are beautifully lit at night!!! Would surely make a detour at night to see

It's an important piece of Cambodian history and it's pretty as far as monuments as this go. But nothing more. It's on a roundabout so have your tuktuk driver make a full circle and make him stop for the mandatory picture and off you go.

If you are taking a walk along the avenue, especially at night when all the locals are on their nocturnal wander & the lights sparkle in the trees, then the monument is nice to see as you pass. But it is basically just a large statue to the previous King, with no information, so
Drive past it every chance you get, you'll spot something new each time. Located on a round about so stopping is hard.
Very impressive monument best seen at night. To be fair we visited at the last night of there annual Independence Day celebrations. So lots of fire works

Located in central Phnom Penh, a roundabout where always seems heavy traffic. Hard to get close to it, but take photos from across the park where you can also see a statue of King Father Norodom Sihanouk.

The monument stands between Norodom Boulevard and Sihanouk Boulevard in the centre of the city.The monument is said to be built in the Angkorian style. This is an impressive structure consisting of five levels decorated with 100 snake heads. Independence Monument was built in

Stunning at night but difficult to cross the road at the crazy round about to actually get to it. The monument is simply that and nothing else so across the road from the actual monument is the best spot for a pic.
We saw he monument whilst passing in a tuk tuk. It’s located on a roundabout so the best way to see it and take photos is to go round the roundabout in a tuk tuk.
This looks spectacular at night and worth a look. There are guards nearby with big machine guns who are not keen for a photo! Worth a look

This monument was in the middle of perhaps the busiest roundabout in Phnom Penh. It was a very recognisable landmark, but was extremely difficult to get to on foot, as there were vehicles coming from all directions. Try and get up close if you're able to, without losing your
There is not much but just a monument there. The closest attraction is Naga Casino and the Mekong river
It's boring in the day light but beautiful in the night light. Don't forget your camera with you! ;)

This place happens to be right in the middle of the city which connects the other tourist attractions with places of stay and thus one would end up there by default. We didn't spend time at the place but for visiting there on a tuk tuk. Holds lot of significance for the country
The independence monument is pretty to look at and when you think of all the trauma this represents, it gave me a shudder,
The view of the monument at night is nice coupled with dazzling vehicles flow. There is a park in the vicinity which can be explored.
Take a Tuk Tuk to see it at night all in lights and the trees are in lights very pretty. I would suggest going in the early morning too because it does get very hot.

Built in 1958 as a memorial to Cambodia's independence from France in 1953. Independence Monument is designed in a Angkorian style, shaped as a lotus temple stupa that consist of five levels and every level is decorated with snake heads. The monument is at it's most impressive
Nothing special, just another of hundreds of monuments in Asia. Set in the middle of a large busy roundabout.
Nice place to take pictures. It is right in the middle of a busy junction so be careful while taking the pictures. This monument looks great when it is fully lit on few days during the evening.
Only interesting to know what it is when you pass by. If you don't pass, you don't really have to go there to visit it.
Everything is in the title! Anyway, since the monument is located on a key place in Phnom Penh, you will certainly have the opportunity to pass close to it.

This is a fairly average looking monument located in the centre of a giant traffic roundabout in downtown Phnom Penh. Getting across to the monument requires a certain level of courage as there really can be a lot of traffic here. Visiting on a weekend probably helps as you just
We visited during a nighttime wander of Phnom Penh. Very grand structure which sits tall amongst the surrounding streets.
good to see at night the area is a nice tuk tuk ride with some one special a lot to see in Cambodia .

When lit up at night and a great place to just sit and people watch and marvel at the tuk tuk drivers and those on mopeds who despite the apparent carnage seem to avoid each other Be wary at night crossing the road though as the city is sadly notorious for drink driving and

The symbol of the Kingdom’s Indepence, it’s one of the must see places when visiting the capital. The park nearby is a great place for an afternoon walk. The monument is lighted up with colored lights in evening and the fountain is up during holidays and special occassion.
Nothing too impressive, but obviously means a lot to the Cambodian people. Newly built it lacks the grandeur of more histoeic cultural sites, but is still definitely worth a quick stop.
NIce and close and easy to see. Cambodians very proud of their monument. My tuk tuk driver was very emotional about it.

The independence monument is a quite nice monument on a nice boulevard. It is kinda chaotic in the evening with a lot of cars and scooters driving around, but it is also a good vantage point when you walk around the city.
I saw this from the tuk-tuk when the driver pointed it out. Took a quick pic and kept going. There are other things to see and do that are a better use of your time in Phnom Penh
A beautiful and picturesque monument in the center of the city. It is free to view and an excellent representation of Cambodian architecture.
in the middle of the biggest roundabout where norodom intersects preah sihanouk blvd...more beautiful at night as many lights illuminate it.
Not a whole lot to do here, but worth going to for sure. Quite the impressive monument, and a bustling area in the city!

This monument in the heart of Phnom Phen depcits or represents the indpencence of Cambodia. Free to view it is set in a park however is in the middle of a busy intersection. Your journey around Phnom Phen will likely take you past this attraction.
It is just a monument on a roundabout, no added extras. But it is very beautiful and commentates Cambodian independence from France. It lies at the centre of the city so well worth a pause to enjoy!

If you're wandering around Phnom Penh, it's impossible to miss this monument. Sat in the centre of one of the busiest roundabouts in the city, it's worth taking a few minutes to have a look at and take a few happy snaps, particularly if you get there around sunrise or sunset.
Cool Monument, can see from your car.. other than that don't make a trip just to see it. Think about what it represents and appreciate what it stands for..

This monument marks one end of Norodom Boulevard. No need to make this a specific get to place, as you will more than likely pass it several times while seeing our sights. The roundabout traffic is hectic so don't be expecting any solemn ambience. Encourage visitors to walk the
Another impressive monument in Phnom Penh, but no need to hop out of your tuktuk and try to navigate through the traffic to get a better look.

You should just drive by it. It is beautiful, with some incredible history behind it but I wouldn't recommend stopping in the middle of a roundabout and take a look. It's still beautiful even while driving past it on your way to the palace.
There's really nothing special about this monument but I think it's the Khmer style. I've seen other similar around the country

There really isn't anything too special. You can photo is from anywhere on the roundabout but you can't get up close unless your driving round the roundabout. Saw it both day and night - both views were good. You're bound to pass it at some point during your stay in the city.
Easygoing didn't cost anything to go there the locals gather around at night and dance great to watch close to restaurants and the water front all flat easy walking

Traveling around Phnom Penh, one is bound to pass this monument many times, and yet even just casually passing by I am always inspired by its simple, spiritual elegance in honor of the human desire to be free. It evokes the past while offering inspiration for the future.
Like much if the old architecture in Cambodia, the skill and creativity of the monument is amazing. We visited at night when it was all lit up. Stunning

It's kind of hard to travel to Phnom Penh without coming across the Independence monument at least once or twice, and as the name implies, it's a monument and nothing much to see, but a nice spot to take a photo and then move along. Don't get me wrong, it's pretty and beautiful,
Grab a tuk tuk and drive past at night they will stop for a photo it's very pretty and shows the intricacies of the architecture.

The monument is very nice to see. We wandered past as it was on our way to dinner. It is nice to walk through the two large park areas between the royal palace and the monument. The monument itself is a round-a-bout, so you can't get up close to it. It was nice to see on our

No need to stop and look at the Monument during the heat of the day, driving by will get you all yoy need. But if you do plan to visit and take photos, go during sunset as you'll get phenomenal colors in the sky and pair that with the beautiful Monument = a beautiful moment!
Just some monuments at the park. Only go if u have time and you will finish walking one end to the other end on foot in 15 mins. No entrance fee is required.
I would recommend to visit this monument at night, if you want to get some nice pictures. Located near the riverside and easy to access.

I visited in the evening to take a night shot of the monument. It is pretty, also together with the other monument. It is hard however to cross the street at that time, as not only a lot of scooter are driving, but also a continuous line of cars at pretty high speed. There is no
Impressive monument based on Angkor Wat shapes. Well highlighted and lit at dusk or night, and therefore best visited both during the day, and after sunset.

A massive monument to Cambodia's independence in the broad park-like median of bustling Sihanouk Blvd. It's a "must-see" even though it won't take long. Stop by the memorial to King Sihanouk nearby, too. Popular locations for locals to shoot, for example, their graduation
Built in 1958, It is a nice monument,we didn't spend a lot of time near it but it was great to visit and have some photos taken!!

I can never get too lost as I use this beautiful Monument to locate where I am in this bustling city. It is especially pretty at night in how well it is lite up - an beautiful spot in Phenom Penh and it is located near the President's house -
No more than a modern stupa in angkorian style. Nice at the evening when you can sit in one of the food stand around the enormous intersection of which the monument is the centre.

The monument is located on a roundabout, there is no way to reach it so it can be seen only from across the road. It is a cool monument but it has nothing really special about it. Max you can spend around it is 5 minutes, just to take 2 pictures.
This photo stop was included in our cyclo tour of the city. It is a stunning monument which is well worth seeing.
Nice to drive past in your tuktuk but that's about it. Good for a photo but don't go out of your way to go there. Not much around it except swarms ofctraffix.

It's a landmark. Am important landmark that has made its way into the Phnom Penh geofilter on Snapchat. Is it worth stopping here? No. Why? Because you're going to cross this monument several times when you're in your tuk tuk or your motto and well... it's a one dimensional
This is the land mark of Phnom Penh so you should visit this monument and also the statue of King Norodom Sihanouk in front of it. Best to see at night, especially after rain.

Just walking around the city after having traditional performance at museum, it was nice walk at night from the nearby King's monument while watching people sitting and walking along the avenue. There are several police guarding nearby around the monuments, probably for some
It was fine just taking it in wuth a drive through though. We passed it in the way to S21 and recognized it. I am not sure if you can even walk round it.

We visited this site in the evening and it was quiet and relaxed. The history attached to this site reminds us of similar structures in other cities around the world. Our guide was full of passion and patriotism when we were discussing this monument with him.
We stopped here to learn more from our guide about the history of the city. This monument is very symbolic to Cambodians. Great fresh coconuts from the roadside vendor, also!

This monument is one of the very few structures (if we can call it that) that is meticulously maintained on a yearly basis. It is also the venue where HRH the King makes his speech during his commemoration day (which is a public holiday) to students who would congregate here

This monument both commemorates Cambodia's independence from France in 1953 and honors their citizens lost in war. It is inspired by the central tower of Angkor Wat. You really can't miss the monument while in Phnom Penh as it is in the center of a busy street.
Just a bit of fun to watch the locals at play and picnic. Nothing much to see really and more impressive at night but an important landmark on festival days.
I asked my tuk tuk driver to drive by and took pictures. It is not a place like where you need more time to spend, you won't miss it because of its proximity to Naga World and central location.

When riding by tuktuk tell your driver to just drive by. Have a look while passing or just make a short stop while going to the royal palace. It's a nice monument but not very impressive in my opinion.
This is the independent monument located centrally in the capital city of Cambodia ,This has a nice view at night with big round about and near to man-gong river.
Found on sihounk Blvd about 7 minutes from Riverside Phnom Penh Cambodia . Opposite you will find the Cambodian prime ministers mansion and North Korean embassy . Take a bottle of water with you.
A lovely place to visit to see the vast cultural differences of our two countries. A must see if you are visiting the country.

It's not the coolest or grandest of monuments, but it is an interesting piece of architecture and you might as well get a picture with it since you're here! Try and stay on the grassy park area that's on the other side of the street from the monument. It'll be a lot safer

This monument is devoted to the Cambodian independence from France in 1960s. It was a great event, and no wonder this magnificent monument reminds it. It is not possible to ignore it walking in Phnom Penh especially during sunset time.

Usually just referred to as the monument, it is in the middle of everything, at the junction of busy Norodom and Sihanouk Boulevards. You will pass it many times during your visit to Phnom Pehn. Most impressive when lighted at night. (Visited 2011-13.)
Just be careful getting anywhere closer to that monument, I think you are safer at a very far distance because the traffic is insane. Defs go at night for a stunning view
This imposing monument is well worth a visit either at night or during the day. At night it is at the heart of the local's after-hours social activities and looks amazing all it up.

The monument celebrates the nation's independence from France. It stands 20 meters tall and was built between 1958 and 1962. It is shaped like a lotus like stupa and was designed by the Cambodian architect Vann Molyvann
History Monument in heart of city, stand in middle of beautiful place around by relaxation garden. Independence monument very greatest designed idea.

The carving is great and it looks awesome at night but its located in the centre of the a median strip down the centre of a major road. You can see it from the tuk tuk or car and also from the many roof top bars. Personally I wouldnt make a specific trip to see it.

It is a big monument in the middle of a big roundabout, not much more than that. It certainly is a landmark in Phnom Penh, but it is not a "visitable" place, just a pass by spot. The boulevard at Preah Sihanouk starting from the monument is okay, a walkable place.
This is an interesting structure. There is very little else to report on this. It's just an interesting to look at structure.
This monument is a great bit of architecture just go have a look as you walk round Phnom Penh if you like stuff like that

I went there with my family and it was really refreshing. There is this Independent Monument and along with it is a park , which is located right in front of it. It's really wonderful. The night view of the sky from the park is breathtaking. I would totally suggest people to go
Our tuk tuk driver stopped off on the way to the Killing Fields to allow us to see this. It doesn't take long to see this attraction.
Independence Monument is typical of these sort if monuments, located in the center of a traffic circle.
Best way to see this is by tuk tuk doing a drive by photo shoot. The roads are busy and there is little else to do around the site.
This is like a huge structure in the centre of the city. The surroundings & liveliness near this place is very good & you can easily spend couple of hours exploring all the nearby lanes

Located on a very very busy roundabout. Nice to see as a main landmark of the city but no need to hang around for long as there's nothing else there to see once you take your photos. Take a Tuk Tuk to drive past that's your best way to view it.
Located in the center of the main boulevard, this is one of the landmarks of Phnom Penh. It is beautiful during the day and at night and it is hard to miss.
It is right in the centre of the road. Must be patient when taking photos as vehicles would pass by every now and then. Had nice photo though.

Chances are you'll drive by - NO NEED TO VISIT! Really! It's pretty at night time but there's nothing to see by stopping so have your camera out (but not snatchable by passing motos) to snap some shots!

The monument is a blast! Powerful and grace. Very well preserved. The only thing that I found difficult is to across the plaza and get there. Cars, bikes, tuktuks, motorcycles; all coming on a non stop way. Nice pictures and history
I walked to there from my hotel. The momentum is in the middle of a roundabout but the area around it is quite nice and well laid out and there are some other interesting statues etc to see

We visited the monument at night and it looked spectacular. The roads don't have much traffic and absolutely no noise. We sat in a park nearby and just observed for good half an hour before cycling away If you don’t have much time you can even miss this one.
The monument itself isn't that big of a deal but it is in this area a lot is happening at night so you should pay it a visit
During the day, it is a common tower. But at night, it rises up among others. It becomes a neck-turner.
Hired tuk tuk driver Sarwar to drive us around so he took as places and one of them was this monument. Pretty impressive monument we must say.
We stayed within walking distance from the independence monument. After Dinner, we walk passed the junction and have a good look at the monument. It was light up and is really a good spot for camera.

This pagoda is right in the heart of the Riverside area. Another Buddhist temple with a number of Buddha images, a peaceful place in a manic area. Worth a visit as it is one of the most important Buddha places in PP.

This is a main route in the city to the river area. It is a place where a lot of activities take place. There are lots of eating and drinking places near this venue. Great place to experience the local people as Sunday is free for all dance at the venue and lots of eating stalls

The monument is open 24hours and has free entry. There is no restriction of clothing either. We were able to see it from our hotels roof top so decided to walk it up. It's a lotus shaped stupa, similar to the architecture at Angkor wat. the grounds surrounding the monument are

It's very near to the Statue of King Father Norodom Sihanouk which is situated in a square. It doesen't take to much time to visit it and it is worth visiting. If you can choose to visit both on the late afternoon/night (by sunset).

In the city center and must see photo op for Phnom Penh. Walk to many other attractions and plenty of good restaurants or cup of coffee and sit in the park. The area is clean and good for just relaxing. Lite up in the evening is very beautiful.

The best part of independence monument is the people -- out exercising and just hanging out! Early morning _ like around 6 a.m. _ or at sunset are the best times as this place can get hot. Also in the evening there are many food vendors
A square in the heart of Phnom Penh. Walkable distance from grand palace and river front. Neat and clean.

This lotus shape pagoda monument celebrates gaining independence from France. It's in the middle of busy round about where two big streets meet. It's not so close to other major attractions, but you can take a 2$ tuktuk there. Once there walk towards the river, around 30 min

It is located at the very crowded roundabout and very hard to take a nice picture here because of high traffic. you can walk to the statue of King, kingdom of Cambodia, Vietnam Cambodia friendship monument. This monument looks nice at night when it lits
This large memorial is in a very crowded roundabout. It is very photogenic but very hard to obtain a nice picture because of the traffic.

I love running in the area surrounding this monument when in Phnom Penh. Early weekend mornings are best, as there are lots of people doing various workouts. While the monument itself is pretty, I suspect you would eventually get bored if all you did was stare at it every time

Visited here whilst in Phnom Penh, the monument is quite impressive and well worth a visit if you are in the city. It's on a busy roundabout and you can't walk right upto it. It's best done at the start of sights in the city, from here you can walk on a nice area to the statue
Beautifully centred in the middle of massive traffic circle. Nice walk around it with other little monuments etc. Its a nice landmark that you can base your city walks around
This whole area is a great place....wide open boulevards with central park.....this monument looks best at night when lit.

Wasn't a very exciting place to go as a singular structure became a bit repetetive to many other better places we had been in cambodia ( temples in siam reap or the royal palace in Phnom penh it self)
A landmark in the centre of Phnom Penh, particularly at night when floodlit as it dominates the skyline.
I was in this attraction last april 7th 2017 after i visited royal palace and silver pagoda. This area is along highway and you can visit it anytime for free.

This monument looks much better at nights and from a distance, so don't come closer, because it's disappointing. Just pass by, take a picture if you like, but it doesn't deserve a special visit. You'll not lose much if will skip this "landmark"
It's ok for taking one photo to mark that you have been to Phnom Penh. It's architecture is interesting. You can read about this from the Internet or guide book.
You're probably going to pass it, and photograph it, but it's not very spectacular - unlike many other nearby buildings

You will pass this place several times while visiting the other attractions in the city.So no need to go especially to see this one. It's a good place to take a walk especially in the evening when the weather is much cooler.

It's a monument. It looks quite pretty at night and is well lit. It's in the center of a busy central traffic intersection. It's clean. It unexceptional, but worth a quick look if you like taking monument pictures at night.
A memorial to Cambodia 🇰🇭 independence, sited in a well manicured boulevard Lots of night time street venders for snacks and drinks A nice peaceful vibe
This place is like being in the middle of LA in the rush hour. But a heck of a lot more interesting. Be careful crossing the road!!!
No need to stop as it's in the middle of a main roundabout. Just slow the car down and take a picture!!!!

The French presented the monument to make the independence from France in 1958. The monument is in the shape of a lotus-shaped stupa which is based upon a similar design at the Khmer Temple at Angkor Wat and similar Khmer historical sites. We booked a Cyclo ride and passed this

The design of the monument is a classical one but being in th middle of a busy square it is a little difficult to appreciate. Interesting for its historical significance even if more recent history is more prominent.
It`s just a monument, nothing more than that. It stands in the middle of a traffic circle and is next to a walking avenue.
The monument in central Phnom Penh A travel hub Beautiful Khmer style. Beautiful day and night. lol lol

text.wiki:
The Central Market (Khmer: ផ្សារធំថ្មី, "Phsar Thom Thmey", "New Grand Market", French: Marché central de Phnom Penh) is an Art Deco landmark of Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia. The bright yellow building completed in 1937 has a 26m high central dome, with four tall arch-roofed arms branching out diagonally across the block, creating vast hallways housing countless stalls and all kinds of goods. Initially designed by city architect Jean Desbois, construction works were supervised by French architect Louis Chauchon.
When it first opened in 1937, it was said to be the biggest market in Asia; today it still operates as a market. 
After Phnom Penh became the capital of the French protectorate of Cambodia within French Indochina in 1867, the population grew enormously and the French set about creating a spacious modern city. The decision to build a market dates back to the end of the 1920s in response to the increase in the population to 90,000 inhabitants. It was decided to build it on a marshland in the center of the Chinatown of the time, but the project did not start until 1934 because of the turmoil of the Great Depression. It was designed by Jean Desbois (1891 Cherbourg -1971 Lorient), the architect of the city from 1931-37, and its implementation will be supervised by Louis Chauchon (1875 - 1945 Saigon) and the ingenue Wladimir Kandaouroff. The works are entrusted to the Indochinese Society of Studies and Construction which has already built the markets of Battambang and Cholon. The marsh was drained and work began in August 1935 and was completed in 22 months later; the market was inaugurated by King Sisowath Monivong in September 1937  . 
Since its completion, wet season flooding around the market has remained a problem, a reminder of the marshland it once was.
The areas between the four diagonal arms and the surrounding streets were originally planted as gardens; over the years the gardens were gradually filled with various temporary structures, greatly increasing the number of stalls.
During the Franco-Thai war in 1941 the market was bombed by Thai aircraft, causing heavy damage, and it had to be temporarily closed. After the end of World War II it was restored much as it was. 
From 2009 to 2011, it underwent a US$4.2 million renovation funded by the French Development Agency. This renovation repaired and restored all the original reinforced concrete structure, and added low arched roofed stall areas in the originally open areas on all four sides.The entrances to the market are lined with souvenir merchants hawking everything from T-shirts and postcards to silver curios and kramas. Inside is a dazzling display of jewels and gold. Electronic goods, stationery, secondhand clothes and flowers are also sold.

== References ==

When we traveled to Cambodia at December 2019, we went there.This place is good for shopping, they dont keep prices too high. But you have to bargain. This is the perfect place for gifts or souvenir items. All kinds of things like wallets, sunglasses, women's jewelry, t-shirts,

Almost everything available for shopaholics but need to be extra careful for imitation goods. USD is highly appreciated here and do bargaining for best prices.

Great place to shop and walk around. You’ll find some bargains here. Take US dollars it seems the Cambodian Riel isn’t worth much and everything you’ll price is in US money? Plenty of places and things to see.

It's a fun must go to market when in Phnom Penh. If you need some souviners t-shirts or clothes or other interesting things it's a good spot. Store holders were friendly enough too! Good place to get a nice meal too like I did for breakfast!

Amazing choice of souvenirs and clothing at reasonable prices Souvenirs and clothes tend to be onnthe outside Inside jewellery ,food,and cosmetics
This huge market was built in 1930's in French Art Deco style. Renovated in the 1990's. It has all sorts of goods on offer such as clothing, jewelry and souvenirs. A real shopping experience.

Visited central market, overall good mostly they sell souvenirs duplicate branded bags and sunglasses. We have to bargain and get a good deal. ( Must ask half or 2/3 price to start with) . We have bought hammock stand here, its Cambodian Easy Swing.
Ive been told to visit this market, but when I saw the amazing architecture, I wanted to know more. It looks like the inside of a Dalek.
Went this morning for breakfast. Open market surrounds the central building. All locals buying fresh produce and meats except for me. Inside is jewelry and tourist trinkets.

Like most good markets in south east Asia this one has it all and depending what you’re looking for it could be really good. Definitely worth a look!
They can give you offer price,i like that😊👍 plus the lady was friendly and nice. Be careful with your phone,wallet and stuff you carry on travellers 🥰🥰🥰

Should have checked. Main part of the market closed. Tuk Tuk driver didn’t tell us it would be. Waste of time really. Fond memories of the market, previously.

Vendors are selling same souveniers. What's interesting will be the wet markets. Quite a enjoyable visit to this market. There isn't any hard selling and the vendors don't bother you even if you ignore them.

Nothing interesting here, just few vendors selling souveniers. They sell jewelleries, cosmetics, clothes, and few other daily things.
close to our Mito Hotel, we bargained with some of the local stall holders and got some great pineapple with chilli sugar and coconut water.
Indoor market with everything from gold jewelry to automobile parts. A little more spread out than a Russian market but a bit more expensive as well.
This is a fun place to barter for fake watches, local souvenirs, t-shirts. The coconut water was delicious!

The markets were interesting, in that the design and architecture was wonderful and unique, but the offerings of the vendors there were fairly standard, and full of typical tourist merchandise and garb.

central market is like many markets around the world. It is full of bustle and activity.As the name implies it is a very central market right in the middle of the city. It is easy to get to, but you have to be aware of traffic on your way. The only way to get there is to make a
Many things coming from China, suitcase, t-shirt electronics, jewelery, souvenirs etc It's a good place for shopping but I closes early around 5pm many shops starts to pack and close

It’s getting very touristy here. Phnom Penh has better markets, with better prices and friendlier locals.

I visited the market out of curiosity. Not as interesting as Russian market. Lots of fruits, dried packaged foods available. If you have old dollar bills that are torn, you can exchange them here. It was a horrible experience to have a dirty 100 dollar note, noone would accept,
Worth visiting this place you can get anything you want. Very big and so much of choices highly recommend

We visited this market in Cambodia that it seems every child of school age learns not only Cambodian but also English that makes it much easier to communicate with the stall owners. It is well set out but does get a little cramped inside the main area. You need to bargain hard

Seafooď eatery fruits cig. Cigars cheap price watches jewellerie clothing wineglasses shues leathergoods luggathes locks etc.

Everyone should visit the Central Market or Phsar Thmey (in Khmer). Interestingly while 'Phsar' means 'market', 'Thmey' actually means 'new' rather than 'Central'. Go figure. This is a good place to get gold (especially the shops surrounding the market), and some local produce.
Enjoyed walking around this historic market and experiencing the local wears. Even bought some and sampled some of the local food too. Great afternoon out.
It's a great place to shop where you can bargain for the price. Worth to check out or spend some hours around.

Its ok and just ok to spend 30mins. Cultural learning is a price less process afterall. Jewellery watches IT gadgets clothing n wet market selling fresh produce

It was big with many shops. However, as a tourist, I am not attract to the gold braces, necklace or the oil paintings that look all the same.

Great range of stalls and ability to bargain with vendors. WE found what we were looking for and were very happy with the price paid. Used PassApp to get tuktuk here.

I enjoyed my visit to Central Market. We weren’t hassled too much by the stall holders. There were all the usual copy items, clothing, bags and shoes. It’s a great place to buy scarves, gifts and there’s lots of jewellery. Stall holders were mostly very friendly but of course

Nothing special, no special discounting, prices comparable to any first world country. You'd feel that sellers not really interested in selling - too busy with their smart phones. Wonder if they really want business.

A reconstructed big hall and other market places for juwelleries, clocks, textils, food, fruits, vegetables and Souvenirs. Enough space for shopping and selling. A must for all visitors of Phnom Penh.
Amazing place to visit, so much to see and too buy, I managed to buy a pair of Hugo boss variofocals with transision, for $100. and they are great. Everything here and good prices!

They are friendly and have many thing in there .I and my friends had been there after finished Killing Field.
After we arrived in the afternoon we have walked to the market and it was closing around 17:00. Not so exciting and tasty as the old market can offer. Good trip!

Had a lovely morning g here.This market is clean and airy .An amazing cool building. Heaps of different stores selling everything .We enjoyed this market alot more than the Russian market .more laid back and easier to shop

We roam arround the place to look for a shoulder bag. The bag that i have bought is not that expensive and not that cheap but it was very nice.

Great time at Central Market.Picked up some great clothing bargains ,especially golf apparel. Well worth a visit with great people and flexible prices.

Well worth a vist. Noisy, busy and authentic. Look around, look up, imagine what this was like in Colonial times,

Whatever you need can be found in Central Market !! The place to get lost and wander around, from flowers to food to leather gods to souvenirs you will definitely find something to buy. The game is to bargain over there. Safe place with nice sellers and again all can be found

Another crazy, crowded market in Asia. Vendors didn’t hassle to much. Worth a visit for the handicrafts and cheap clothes
I always visit the market in every country or city I visit. I like to see the local fruits and veg. I was not impressed by this market, at all!!

Just down the road from our hotel, within walking distance. Many markets, do not pay note than 3USD for sarongs or pants.

We walk arround.we can find whatever we need here.crowded place.many electronics gadget stores with good price.

The central market is highly visited by tourist to buy souvenirs like jewelry shoes and clothes. This market is located in the center of the city and you’ll also find electronics and gadgets that are cheaper compared to the mall

Clean market. I loved the souvenirs I bought. Dresses for 7usd each, don't know if that is a bit pricy. 7usd for 10pieces of coin purses with elephant designs which I loved by the way. I bought kitchenwares for 5usd to 7usd.

It;s a market that you could shop anything, over there from clothing to Dry seafood and to souvenir like Art piece and Statues.It would be good to be there in a cloudy half day trips otherwise you be melt under the hot SUN in Cambodia.

A must see to get some amazing photos or just incredible sights of fresh local produce in their wet market. But also loads of shops to buy fake luggage and clothing and souvenirs and jewelry. Don’t forget to bargain .
Rather large market selling all sorts of products. Good place to shop for souvenirs, grab a bite to eat or simply go sightseeing.
Good market to find cheap t shirts and souvenirs, very big so allow for plenty of time to wander round and check out the food you can munch on crickets tarantula spiders ect

First Stop of the day: Another market to catch the morning local buzz of people buying and selling food. It's much bigger than the russian market with many sections. If you need something local, this place probably has it. My wife wanted one of them folding cushions and managed

Wonderful place to visit with all kinds of goodies. Jewellery, watches, clothing, ather goods including travel. One of the best I’ve visited throughout the world and only a dollar or two in a tuk tuk from anywhere in PP. A must see 👌
All kinds of stuff for sale, for locals as well as tourists. Got all souvenirs here..... caps, glasses, T-shirts, bags, wallets etc. Bring U.S. dollars in small denominations, & haggle yer socks off!
A good place to visit if you plan to check out jewelery, precious stones, clothes, bags and shoes. Must bargain if you wish to have a good offer. In-door and outdoor stalls.

It is a pleasant market to visit, there were some interesting stalls but mainly it was all clothes apart from the central jewellery area. There was some food stalls found hidden out the back which was a busy, bustling area with some excellent choices of food, from huge prawns
Impressive huge market so many stalls with good variety of stock. Was very hot inside when we were there, take a fan.

There’s every kind of up and down market wear available in this mountainous shopping arena, don’t go with the first price as you would have been told. Bargaining is a Cambodian past time and its well worth it.

We visited the market a few times during our holiday. You will find terrific food and juices to eat and drink, as well as heaps of beautiful things to buy for low prices. Just haggle until you got half the price they were asking. Heaps of fun.

We visited Central Market a few times and everyone happy with purchased. Although lot of things were more expensive than last year. There is a huge variety of things to buy especially clothing, jewellery and electronics. Well worth the trip.
It’s a modern building and very airy. Great bargains to be had if you haggle! Typical SE Asian products.

Been there a good place to see the big dome construction, more of Islamic type, it's a place for shopping clothes and cheap electronics, souvenirs, imitation jewelry and lot of short eats around It's a must visit place but the bad thing is they close by 5.30 pm so day time
Everything in multiples and so much bling. If you want a watch, this is the place. Plenty of clothes and bargains to be had. We bought a kimono and several Tin Tin T shirts and some "Gucci" sliders.

The central market is probably best known for its jewellery range. Buyer beware however - the US$13 Rolex watch probably won’t work for long! There is also a huge range of clothes, food, electronics, flowers and ornaments. Prices are very reasonable - for example shirts and
Fab clothes and glitter market. Bargain hard for a 30% reduction. Amazing architectural space. French 1935 industrial architecture, restored in 2000.

Great market with everything you dream to buy. Its good to bargen, as it works!!!! I enjoyed it. I bought a big backpack, good quality and giod price. The people want to sell but they are polite and helpful.
You will find shops like these everywhere in Cambodia and Southeast Asia. The building itself is nothing special.
Umpteen small units, each about 1.5 into 1.5 meters in area, selling local produce. It’s my second visit here. It’s safe.

Love this market as the people are not as pushy as Russian market. The fruit juice serve good avocado juice. The food stalls here all too nice. Fresh and1 reasonable price. Try eating noodle and sit at their low and smallish

A neat domed building in the center with plenty of shopping options from the local sellers. If you think the price is too high, just go to the next stall and ask for their price. I got prices anywhere from $12 USD to $2.5 USD for a set of nice chopsticks. It pays to shop
Prefer this market over the Russian market! Had a great selection of gold and silver jewelry among clothes and other souvenirs.

The building by itself is very interesting - big dome with several wings. The central part is filled with jewelry , different gem stones , silver , some gold . On the sides you find clothes , shoes , souvenirs. The quality is not very good to be honest . Don’t forget to bargain

It is a centrally located market with all the usual items like clothes, shoes, artifacts, toys, stuff for kids. Must visit. Bargaining will help. Vendors are polite and welcoming. Lots of tuk tuk outside to go back to hotel. Local food stalls are plenty for non vegetarians. One

Great market with lots on offer. However once you've been to one market you've been to them all... There are lots of people shouting at you trying to get you in their stall but it's all part of the experience

It is a magnificent bargaining place and you can get copy all branded items at very cheap prices. The dome is the biggest for any municipality public place and market. we can spend hours shopping with less prices.

Same as most Asian markets. Building is old and worth a look. You can’t really browse because as soon as you stop they want to know how much you will pay for it, but did feel overly harassed here. Brought a couple of trinkets but still felt that I had got ripped off. This

As a tourist from SE Asia, a market is nothing new to me. So, the only reason I came to visit the Central Market is to admire on the building architecture, which is of course amazing and get some good photos of it. This market sells both wet and dry stuffs, but I am not too
I like vibrant real smelly markets, this one features mostly cheap clothes and cheap jewelry. The central dome is nice, that's about it for me.
The central market is like any other market in South East Asia hot and sticky, however Central market in Phnom Penh is housed in a very nice Art Deco building that is worth a visit just to see that
If you look for things to buy before going back home. It's a good place to go and spend a time. But ensure don't miss to bargain for a better price :-)

If you want a t shirt, they have your size or so they keep telling you! Souvenirs, Shoes, Clothes, Watches etc is the place to go but be warned in extremely warm inside. The fans are a welcome relief but not a lot of them. Inside markets during the day and night markets outside
So much all kind of stuff. There is everything, even meat that has spent all day in the heat and sun. Worth to bargain when you buy.

This market with its big dome is a place for everything. It was pretty crowded with mostly locals. You can get clothes, food stuff, souvenirs and everything else. The guide did not come with us but told us that you can bargain. We had already picked up souvenirs in Siem reap.
This market is busy. Easy to get to via a tuk tuk. Must bargain hard as they start very high. The sellers can be a little pushy but not too bad. The Russian market is better.
We had a stroll through Central Market when we came upon it unexpectedly while 'discovrting' Phnom Penh on foot. Nothing special. Interesting to see the 'dai pai dongs' or cooked food stalls.

This would give you a flavour what a day to day Cambodian’s requirements would be. You can find their staple food, sea food, clothes, accessories and stuff. I did not buy anything here as I was wary about the quality of products there. But just walk through the place to

After dinner, we strolled over to the Central Market (right nearby). Unbelievable how many stalls there were. We got a good buy on some clothes. People were polite and not pushy. Very crowded, and not just with tourists. A must see place - especially the foot massages in
it was good time at central market to know the city life of the Phnom Penh. I will suggest everyone to visit this place at least once in your travel at Phnom Penh.

We went here to find some shoes and found the prices to be set very high for knockoff shoes. We were fine with the knockoff aspect, but several sellers seemed hesitant to budge at all on their prices. The architecture of this place is interesting, and if you shop around, you can

We were famished after the Tamao wildlife rescue park visit in the morning. Reached the market in the afternoon. Not much food choices but we managed to order some fish and noodles. A lot of flies so cannot expect good hygiene. We prefer Russian market than central market. Night

When you go to Central Market be prepared for lots of the same choices with different prices. Lots of interesting smells and food selection. This is an example of how most of the people live. The shops are friendly but push a lot for a sale. It is something of an experience but

It's an experience coming here to shop, I recommend giving it a try! You can find everything from souvenirs, food, clothes, purses, electronics, to motorcycle parts. Plan on bargaining and bring lots of small USD. The are lots of knock off brand items here. If you buy more

What was meant to be a souvenir shopping trip turned out to be a jewelry shopping spree. I couldn't take my eyes off the different colorful stones, rings and earrings wherever I turned. Be careful, though. Make sure you buy from a reputable seller.

The Central Market, a landmark building in the capital, the art-deco Psar Thmei (literally 'New Market') is often called the Central Market, a reference to its location and size. It was built in 1937 and the huge domed hall resembles a Babylonian ziggurat some claim it ranks as
This is a pretty large market which is your typical Asian market. In general the fresh food and meals are sold outside around the outside and goods mainly inside.

Yes, an interesting spot to stop off at and a few interesting sights but nothing extraordinary except possibly the scare stories of pick-pocketing etc. Just take normal care and enjoy the sights, smells and sounds. Does get very busy. Lots of "genuine fakes".

This market is super large and with 4 entrances . I stayed in PP for 4 days and went there for 3 times. Some of the shop even provides english menu. If you are backpackers with limited budget, central Market is a good choice. Please be careful of there food conditions with you

Nothing special about this market, lots of clothes and food. Jewelry was in the center. Food stalls included lots of seafood. My wife saw one of our small fury friends running across the aisle so don’t scream if you see one

As the name implies the market is in the centre of Phnom Penh (the main area). It is a large, diverse market with stalls selling all sorts of things. Not necessarily geared toward tourists, I saw a lot of people there, probably expats, buying fresh fruit and vegetables. The
Some stalls accept credit cards. But russian market is a lot more cheaper and affordable. Be sure to lower your price.

This is the main market in Phnom Penh, a modernised version of Asian markets. The clothes & shoes are cheap, the quality reasonable. We bought genuine(?) polarised Ray Ban sunglasses for US$8. When battering start at a third the asking price & stay at this amount until the

Market was very clean and stalls presented well compared to some others we have come across. After you walk past one stand though, they all have the same thing. We went and had a look around but left empty handed. There were quite a bit of stalls but not as much variety as

I made a quick visit there during the low tourist season and it was fairly quiet so easy to navigate through the market. The prices were quite reasonable and there was a wide variety of clothing and jewelry available. Overall a nice place to visit.

There are numerous shops selling fake brands but in the centre is a lady selling glasses/sunglasses. Ask for "Theary". She is on the West side. If you bring your prescription with she gets it made at about half the price we in the west (Australia). They come with a script
I like Russian market more. Although central market is more organized than Russian market but most shops sell the same thing!
Quite a big market with many different kinds of shops - very 'local styled ' closes , shoes , hair salons , etc.

The market is huge. It has practically anything and everything in there. There were jewellery, clothes, shoes, bags, homeware, kitchen equipment, food- dry and wet market, eateries, hairdressing and beauty services. I got a manicure in there, and my nails look great! Well

We visited here on our last day to find some bits to take home, bought a coupleof Cambodian style BBQ pans as they have a great kitchenwares/utility section. Also has clothes, jewellery, watches, electronics and some small souveniers. We bought a couple of lovely paintings here

The market comprises both wet and dry area, selling a wide range of items from clothings, accessories, neccessities to local food (fresh/cooked) etc. You can also try haggling the price with the stall holders if you wanted to purchase any of their items.
We loved the Central Market. It was really interesting, great value for money and the architecture was truly something to see. Fantastic we thought.
All stall holders are open to bargaining. The range of goods for sale is huge. In addition it is perfect place to try local food. Usually gets very hot inside the hall.

Even the sellers were oppressed by the heat and humidity during our visit, many laying on the stall floor under a fan. I purchased some pirate ear phones for a good price, yet to see how they perform.

Awesome market, selling everything you ever wanted. It is so much improved from when I was here first, more than 20 years ago. It is a nice respite from the hot sun outside too. Best market in Phnom Pehn and wonderful building too. Always worth a visit when you are in the city.

If you want to buy cheap souvenirs to bring home, this is the place to go. For example : a fridge magnet costs about USD$2-3 in the Central Market & a pack of 6 key chains also for the same price. But if you buy from the airport duty free shop, it would cost USD$2 for just 1

This is a day time market and different from the others. The jewellery available is stunning and the electronics on offer are all a great price. There is tourist police available outside, should you have any problems. A safe and nice experience

Visited as part of a tour group. Huge area, so have a meeting point !!!.Different to a market in UK, odd to see ladies having pedicure & manicure.....hair coloured etc....loads to buy, fashion, jewellery, flowers, paintings, lunch stalls.....the list was endless. All very

Interesting market with great architecture. Its quite large and well laid out. Prices are not as cheap as other countries in South East Asia but its still a lot of fun and there is plenty of opportunity to get souvenirs or clothes.....If you want it, its here!
Well worth a wander through here for just about everything. You can have items made to measure here, nails done, hair done, a one stop shop! When shopping barter hard.

This market has spectacular architecture with a cool inner dome and radiating arms filled with all kinds of market goodies from clothes to fresh produce, and everything in between. The jewelery part is huge and not seen so much in other markets. Bargain kindly; it must be so

It's a pretty cool marketplace and a lot of it is in the shade or has canvas over it or is inside of a building. It's really fun shopping but I think prices are better at the night market fairly close by. for example a stick of barbecued shrimp they were trying to sell us for

I personally wasn’t keen on this market, I felt hassled and uncomfortable it’s more a market for the locals especially the food area, I found daunting with some smells I would’ve rather not smelt. But there you go your in Cambodia so you have to embrace it and go for the

There are certain things at Central market (in Khmer they called it "New market") that are really great to buy. If you're looking for a watch or audio electronic equipment (ex. Earphones), this is a great place to go. Tons of options and selection. There are a variety of

On our annual trips to Phnom Penh we usually visit this market several times. It’s centrally located and easily accessed from its well planned entrances. We ask our Tuk Tuk driver to drop us off at an entrance, recognised by a nearby landmark, (a building or sign) and set a time

You have to visit Central Market when in Phnom Penh but go early in the morning as it can get really hot and stuffy. There are lots of aisles of clothes, shoes, toys, electronics etc mostly copies and souvenirs if you like that sort of thing this is the place and at good prices.

This place is very easy to get to in Phnom Penh and should be a must stop for anyone who wants to have some kind of keepsake after they've visited Cambodia. The shape of the building is most unique too. It's almost like a cut in half beehive dome shaped top, (and light yellow in

If you have forgotten to bring something on you're travels you can get a replacement here. You can get everything you need (and a lot that you don't need but want, here) very cheaply, Clothes, electricals, jewellery, watches, bags, shoes, food and a lot more besides.

Great markets under cover but if you like the challenge of haggling and finding anything copy/fake and it being workable is a challenge. Runners are a bargain but sizing is questionable, also double check sizing before you leave the markets.

It was hot hot in the noon as I was visiting there but it is a nice place for all the items you would want to buy--from kramas to handicrafts and readymade t-shirts and so on...so many shops and people to see around. enjoyed it.

Plenty to choose from souvenirs to clothes. Still I find it a little bit overprices. If you do both Phnom Penh and Siem Reap, just do your shopping in SR as I find things a little bit expensive in PP.
Good Place, nice play area for kids and food places. Near to central market which is famous for low price shopping

Went to the Russian Markets yesterday, power was out and there were a lot of the same stalls in a confined space. Central Markets is huge in comparison though a lot easier to get lost and loop back through the same passages. Lots of opportunities to negotiate price or walk away
Not the best market be prepared to bargain as there start prices are3 an 4 times over what it’s worth .
Spent a few hours wandering the market for local treasures. Lovely people and also quite fun bargaining for items.

It’s a market with history. The traders weren’t pushy and there is plenty to buy. We went for the atmosphere and it was an interesting experience. If you don’t like markets then don’t go. But the buildings itself is interesting to look at.
Visited this place on my first day in Phnom Penh and was amazed with the items theyre selling! Even bought some souveniers for my fam and friends!

I have been to a few large markets in South East Asia so knew what they are like. This is no exception. Clothes everywhere, food everywhere. I particularly liked the flower section. Looked great smelt even better
This market is a must visit. They sell quality merchandise at very good prices. They have a variety of items and wonderful souvenirs for family and friends
Almost everything selling here such as souveniers , clothes, t-shirt, watch, cameras and gadgets, food and drinks.
It is big local marakets where locals sell everything for both locals and tourists. We didnt end up buying anything, but it was good to look around... Alot of fruits and fresh flowers too !

Visited in early April, wonderful variety of local crafts and clothing. Great displays of local fruit, vegetables and meat and fish on display. Nice to walk through a market and not be hassled by the stall owners to buy something as is the case in Thai land or Bali. Very
The building is nice with it's art deco dome if you are in the area. The shops are all full of mass produced cheap rubbish and tourist tat.
Amazing hub of colour,people,lifestyles. worth a visit. I went twice, once with a complete stranger ( another story !) & second, with my camera

Loved this place. You do get turned around with some many entrances and exits. You can buy just about anything you can think of from fried tarantulas to shampoo to clothing to jewelry. What a fun tourist experience
Lot of local shop , with variety of goods : cloths , food , jewelry etc . Do not hesitate to bargain on price

The central market is a place to shop for souvenirs and cheap eats. You can find local food and exotic insects at the market. Make sure you bargain when it comes to shopping for clothes and souvenirs! Stall owner usually mark up the price. There are paid public toilets in

I’d visited The Central Market on a weekday at around 4pm plus. It was not crowded at that time probably as it was near their closing time. Good place to scout for T shirts, children’s clothes. It was not as stuffy inside the market compared to the Russian Market. Quite an

I was here 6 years ago and went straight back when we arrived.Depending what you are after it could be a complete waste of time but I was after mens and womens clothing.Lots and lots of stalls going off in different directions .Kitchenware was good too.Tourist items slightly

We stayed nearby so were able to walk there. Definitely worth a visit, lots to see and prices were reasonable. Take note of where you enter as it all looks much the same once inside. Carry USD for purchases. We visited later in the day, it was not crowded and quite relaxing to

Okay, so unless you have a plan to buy something specific it's the same as any major market in any Asian city. Worth a look if you have time to kill, but after 10 min in 40+ Deg heat and over 80% humidity we had had enough

We visited this market today and it is huge! We were not looking for anything in particular but there is pretty much everything you would expect from a Asian market I found the walk through the food market fascinating. The building itself is worth seeing. A word of advice though

A place where copies of brands are sold! Expensive for rubbish quality spare your trip to there unless you are going to spend your money on rubbish A few roads away you can but cloths for half the price the rest you don't want to buy nor bring home

First of all, the building is beautiful and adds a character to the city. The market is fairly clean but it is absolutely huge and can get very crowded. As it is with other markets, the vendors all sell similar things, foods, services. Good place to drop by.
Good place to go if you want a bargain but once you have been to one you have seen them all. As it’s indoor it can get very hot, go first thing in the morning.

The building is a French colonial structure with a distinctive look. Inside is filled with stores/stalls filled with clothes, jewelry, and the usual souvenirs. Nothing you couldn’t find anywhere else.

LOCATION We stayed at the “Le grand palais boutique” hotel (see my review) which is 2 blocks away. The bus station is also nearby, as we returned on an overnight bus from Siem Reap arriving about 06:00 am and walked to find breakfast nearby. CENTRAL DOME Despite the opening
This is a must see attraction with something for everyone and I always buy local handicrafts here each trip for friends at home

The exterior is just small shops, somewhat categorized for what you are looking for to a point. But most items you can find at regular street vendors and small shops throughout. Most merchants are outdoors with makeshift covering leading to the main building. The building

I found this market to be much cheaper than the “Russian market” and had a much more varied goods on sale, stall holders would have a good haggle which I find, strangely this year, not in the Russian market. Very clean also.

I don’t handled harassment well and while interesting to observe and I’m sure there are bargains galore to find the stench from the wet market area is best avoided. The flowers are beautiful and there is choice galore when it comes to jewellery, silver ware, clothing and bags

Excellent market which caters to all your shopping needs. It's indoors so gets you out of the sun and has everything from jewelry to clothes to food. I brought tons of stuff here, a must see if you, like me, like to buy gifts for family and friends.
If you are planning to visit Phnom penh, and looking to buy loads of cambodian Souvenirs, this is the place!! Don't go anywhere else, or buy from any other place. Prices are best, mind boggling!!

To be honest it was a bit of a waste of time nothing different to any market you would find anywhere in Asia Not to sure what I was looking for I suppose I was looking for something to excite me It’s very hot and humid Mike
Central Market is one place where we can get a lot of local Silks, handicrafts, souvenirs etc. However, one should bargain to get a good deal.

Even if you don’t want to buy anything, spend an hour or two in this market with something for everybody. The prices may differ from salesperson to salesperson. Walk around and barter before you start shopping. If you feel something is too expensive, go to the next “shop”. But

Very close to my hotel on 136 street. The building is beautiful. The inside is like a Warren with rows of stalls coming of from the central area.. suppose it's like being inside an octopus. Like most Asian markets the stalls are selling clothes and trinkets with the ones under

The only reason a visitor should see this place is if she’s interested in architecture. But this will take all of five minutes, as you take in the interesting dome from the interior of this market space. In terms of a shopping trip I wouldn’t bother, unless you’re some kind of
The central market is covered, cleaner and easier to navigate than some of the markets visited in other Cambodian cities.

Good place to grab some Cambodian souvenirs to bring home.Bargaining is a must but prices are more reasonable unlike in some countries like Egypt where prices are inflated unreasonably high.Pay what you think the item is worth.Lots of counterfeit things which I don't have much
Very hot and crowded. If you don’t like crowds and being approached, this is not the place for you. It is fascinating watching the locals and stall holders. Don’t forget to haggle!
The French-built building is huge and designed to let air flow through. So many stalls to see, both for tourists and locals. Well worth a visit

A huge market, open everyday, with everything you could ever want or need....IF you can find it! One of the cooler markets in Phnom Penh, well worth a visit, be prepared to haggle & probably get lost!
Great place for shopping, better price comparing to Russian Market and other shopping mall. Lots of selection of items , very organise venue.

CM is a popular and by Asian standards unhassled market. You can find everything here from buddha statues to gold, from the rip-off T shirts to food markets. The building is interesting and it really worth the visit but beware it gets hot....

My wife and I came to the market to look for some souvenirs from our Cambodia trip and found what we were looking for.The Central market is huge and filled with everything you could imagine,we spent hours wandering around and unlike some of the other markets the sellers weren't
Great variety, you can buy everything. Take some cash im sure you will buy something. Well worth a morning visit

They have a little bit of everything, flowers, clothes, shoes, trinkets, food, produce. They will bargain but just about 20 percent. The quality is not that great but it is good for souviners.

This was described as a must do, but we didn't think it was great. The good part is nice to see - very colourful fruit and veg, but the main central part was just fake tat and not really of interest to us.
Good place to pick up alsorts of clothes and luggage the vendors are happy to haggle and don't seem as stressed as some
Huge market with multiple arms from a central location. Jewellery, clothes, seafood, meat, fruit and veggies, this market has it all.

You get everything you are looking for at the central market. Try it! It is fun, though I never knew, where I entered or left the building, cause it is really huge. Prices depend on what you need, of course, but mostly you can deal out a good price. I loved it!

This is a crazy busy place where tons of knock off designer bags,clothes and scarfs can be found. One great bargain are packs of 100-real notes (worth 2-1/2 each) which is crisp and new and great handouts to family and friends when you return home.

Every thing you can think of; traditional scarves, packets of nuts, fresh produce, modern clothing, souvenirs of all kinds....and for a bargain too. Don't hesitate to bargain with vendors and if you don't get the price you want, try another stall because you might get the exact

The cramped closeness of overstocked stalls, the smells of cooking, the crowds... all make this type of market somewhere which is difficult not to explore. A long line of Monks receiving alms of food all adds to the interest. The Memsahib loves it .

bargain and you will get very good pricing. start from half of what they quote or may be even lesser if you are brave enough. the ladies dont get angry but will bargain with you making sure you buy from them. the ladies are always smiling and are always ready to help you out

There is a lot of everything everywhere crammed into such small area. Everything is usually made by a family member even though multiple stalls sell the same items. Take your time to look around before bartering for a better deal. The outside has lots of different foods with
Everything you would expect at a Thai, Vietnam, Cambodian market. Fresh produce, meat and vegetables, clothes, souvenirs, junk and everything else usually Very inexpensive
Large impressive structure but full of tat. All stalls the same. Don't go near the meat and fish area if you have anything like a weak stomach.

The Central Market was not as overwhelming as the Russian Market, which was larger and more crowded. There were many stalls outside the main building. The stalls contained a mix of trinkets, clothes, jewelry, everyday housewares, and food items. Be prepared to haggle for your

It’s a slightly disappointing market when you compare it to the likes of Thailand, Laos and Vietnam but it has some good bargains and stalls. Unfortunately not that much variation in the items for sale - it’s all kind of similar from stall to stall. Impressive building though.

This is the place to bargain to your hearts content. Whatever price they offer you, cut the price in half and go a little lower than that half cut price. So if they say $6, you offer $2. Walk away and they will call you back to sell it to you for $2. Your minimum buying price
Phnom Pehn in general is the most expensive place in Cambodia, add to that the crowds, smog and low standard of local food and you may want to consider flying into Siem Reap.
They selling clothes, watches, some jewelry. Surprisingly they also sells groceries and seafood(very big fresh water prawn/lobster).

From all the reviews we were expecting this to be a bustling market with many items on offer. Maybe our timing was off as there wasn't much at all and we were done in less than 15 minutes. The only markets selling goods was on the outer rim.

It's a kind of place where you can spend an hour or so buying souvenirs for family and friends. Most of the stuff here is of very poor quality so if you are buying t-shirts or other garments, do not expect them to last long. Also, you will need to do a LOT OF BARGAINING here.
Like other markets in Asia,a mix with wet markets,food stalls and clothes,daily necessities...etc. Always nice to visit the market and get a vibe of how local lives and eat.

What a chaos and so much stuff: clothes, jewelry, underwear, food, flowers, electronics, household supplies. You name it and it’s here. Would recommend to keep a close eye at your bag. There are atm’s, toilets and you can eat (if you have a strong stomach) and drink.
No matter how much it is, but don’t forget to bargain the price. It could 20 to 30% down from original price. The items for souvenirs from Cambodia.

Not as big as russian market - fewer stalls for souvenirs. Try the food stalls. Bought banana crackers, dried mangoes and kapot pepper here. Liked the Red pepper seeds compared to the black or white seeds. Really expensive at airport. Quite a few shoes stalls. Almost bought a
