Good deals, interesting downtown area. Batiks and buddhas are beautiful. Silk sarongs and local food is available. Prepare to haggle

The market is nice and you can find all the things that you can image. All false of course do not think that the iphone there are the original one 😂 or the t-shirt adidas, nike, levys... But goof prices and a lot of shadow in the super hot days of Cambodia. The worst part the
Big market with different kind of products in a nice building. More for tourists than the other markets in town. You can buy toys, clothing, juwelery, food and souvenirs.

It’s the first market we have been to in Phenom Penh but we have visited many other markets in other countries. This one was nice, clean and covered. It was well- organized and the people did not seem to be as pushy. We bought several items and they were a good value.

The central market in Phnom Penh wasn’t busy when we went there, but it can get pretty busy at times. The place has all kinds of nick nacks, bits and bobs. It isn’t particularly an interesting place, but the flower market is pretty beautiful. Here you can see women putting

central market in the central of phnom penh, in fact this market is common market for tourist, organised very well, we can find all cambodian souvenier, local food, local fruits and everything but the price is slightly high, maybe most of visitor in central market are tourist
I like this market the best. Bigger selection than the other two bigger markets and definitely friendlier atmosphere then the night market.

The market has a large jewellery section in the middle,and it has sections with different types of clothing. Outside tends to be cheaper for similar things, but be prepared to haggle, or get ripped off. There are many types of street food stalls,that sell all manner of tasty
The market is safer than most yet the wife may need a wheel barrow just to carry the money she will spend. Dont forget to bargain.
The live animals on sale for eating were off putting otherwise lots of Cambodian goods on offer. Very hot inside, watch your valuables !!!
Good for trinkets and souvenires, any clothes or footwear will be for smaller sizes it is still a local market, gems and gold inside but me personally would never buy such in a market

We spoke to some locals before going here and they said - you will be charged double of what everything is worth so whatever they say cut in half. If they say no then say ok and walk off. They will soon come back to you with a reasonable price. Lots of everything can be bought

Friday 11th January and we paid a visit to this large market which is housed in a unique Art Deco building which is a landmark in Phnom Penh. The dome shaped building has four arms branching out from it, from the outside it sort of resembles a train station. Inside the dome

its a cool, big and enclosed shopping place. has a huge collection of multiferous items. need to bargain to get a good price. sellers are too keen to sell their items. overall very good for the shopping lovers.....

I have always enjoyed shopping at the central market This trip the vendors were really hungry and willing to deal and discount on anything and everything. If you need something don’t go to the big mall!!!! central market is the best place to go for the best prices.
Enclosed market carrying all the usual trinkets sold on street corners and markets throughout the country. Have fun as you walk through and barter.
Nothing special to see...fake and cheap things and souvenir and rush, rush, rush...around market is very dirty.
Nothing specials, the typical mix of food stalls and various merchandise....overall, the vendors are not as pushy as in other markets in Vietnam and Cambodia....

Somewhere that the less fortunate can make a living from the more fortunate. Don't be afraid. Find a concrete bench and drink in the way that things are done here. Be warned that the food area is very smelly Gold area is overpriced and the clothing area has many copies.
The Art Deco building that houses the Central Market will be of interest to fans of architecture. We preferred the Russian Market for shopping but we didn't spend much time here.

Nice shopping place. Sell a kind of stuffs mainly non-authentic if u looking at international label. Please make sure u bargain.. usually can go avg 30% lower. There is a local eatery there selling local food. Good food but hygiene wise.. u decide..
Small small shops arranged on the wings of a Hexagon. Got a Tin-Tin Cambodia version T-shirt. Nothing so interesting.

It is worth going here just to see the structure itself as it is quite amazing. You can find almost everything in this market and the surrounding area. You can find some wonderful coffee shops around here and they know how to make a good coffee in this town.
It's worth a visit. Good prices on merchandise. Didn't stay too long but did end up buying a bracelet for a good price.

We had a nice coffee at a place on the corner of the market called 53rd on central. We’d been to the Russian Market first which is a tad more authentic and also cheaper than the central market but the decor and architecture of the Central market makes it more interesting

It is always good to visit the Central Market. There is always a lot of lively activity in and around the fabulous mustard-coloured 1930s French construction. There were bargains to be had and interesting people to meet.

Same old crap for sale, just more of it in one place. I think the Russian Market is better. The building is nice to wander through, but you will find nothing here you haven’t seen before. Better t-shirts in Siem Reap.

We visited this market and found things to be reasonably priced if you after haggling. Generally, we got 50% off the asking price. Lots of jewellery, T-shirts, shoes, electronic goods and food. The building was nice and the location was not too crowded.
Same goods as any other market in the area but the architecture is interesting. We didn't buy anything there but if you want something they will have it.

OK if you need to get something for your trip. There was a good variety of items such as fresh fish, fruit and veg, daily essentials such as toilet paper and jewellery. I saw more tourists than locals when I went.
Good place to strike a nice deal, it can get a bit crowd inside, the mid area are a lot of the same stuff, like most of the markets in Cambodia. The fresh food area were nice and clean.
We got a few bargains from here. Very nice market with a variety of clothes glasses to buy. Clean toilets and a lot of tuk tuks outside of you get tired of walking. Definitely worth a visit
Well worth a visit. Prices same as around town, some traders will however discount for more than one item.

Interesting place for wide varieties of shops though most of them sell quite similar products...however, be wary of certain stalls which sell fruits and food stuffs, they seemed to have two prices for their goods, one for foreigners and one for local ! If you sense they are
Try to bargain as much as possible because they will set a very high price for foreigners. It’s not a good behavior of the sellers.

You would surely find a sourvenir there due tothe massive number of stalls and merchandise available. You are strongly encouraged to initiate bargaining... just remember to enjoy the whole process of bargaining with the vendors. They are very friendly and usually will give you

Visited the central market to have a look around mainly as a attraction point and nothing in mind in particular to purchase. Lot of shops for watches, ornaments, wooden and silver articles, dresses, bags, electronics, mobiles, etc etc are located on different wings, in the
We had a blast wandering and sampling! See the real Phnom Penh. The people are friendly and very polite!

Absolutely huge market in the heart of Phnom Penh- hundreds of stalls selling everything from clothing to fish. You can find a knock-off of just about anything here if you look hard enough. The overall experience can be quite overwhelming- it's crowded and there's a lot going

Very interesting place. Buzz of activity. Found prices to be very high here. So go here after you get a sense of what things cost. Or I think you will be ripped off...Cambodians are lovely people but they will overcharge you. Night markets are better
Interesting market to visit and kill some spare time. They sell almost anything inside. The flower part was very nice.
So many stalls and vendors, you can get so lost in here. Don't lose track of any travelling companions, you may never see them again. :)

Central market was interesting and is worth a visit. Big undercover market in an interesting building. Had a central clock and the stalls are varied and fun. Stall owners are open to negotiation (they start at very high prices, but come to a reasonable price) and are generally

I don’t know the excitement really about visiting Central Market except that’s it’s in the middle of the city close to everything. You can get good prices on food and clothing etc. But new state of the art malls are opening around town, and Central Market feels stuck in the
Worth the stop some souvenirs most mostly you will find fake merchandise. Wasn’t as hot as the Russian Markets.
My girlfriend is fond of jewelry so went to the market and bought some silver ones. Negotiated the price and bought a handful of pieces for my boo.
It is overcrowded and hot inside. If you walk around for a while, you find the same kind of shops over and over. Beautiful building though. And we found a small shop inside that sells great coffee.

The central market is a bustling place where you can find all range of things. Be aware it can be very hot as you wander around and quite crowded. The central dome area filled with 100,s of stalls is impressive.

Central market or Psar Thmei was built in 1937 and is a beautiful art deco dome with four "arms" branching out. The impact inside is of a huge, light filled space. An outdoor market surrounds the building (mainly clothes, fresh vegetables and fruit) whilst indoors there are
Plenty of choices of local products in this market. Especially live seafood was very good with reasonable price

I spent several days wandering around looking, haggling and doing deals. At the market everyone has enough grasp of English to be able to communicate with. You have to Bargain, once you get the hang of it its fun. plenty of variety and a lot of the same, something for everyone
Lots and lots of clothes and jewelry. Not a lot of souvenirs. Interesting to see food market in the building. If you want souvenirs, go to the Russian market - much more fun and better selection.

I realize that all stall holders are trying to make a living, but we have been to many markets on our trip to Cambodia, and both my wife and I remarked that the stall owners here were remarkably unfriendly - in stark contrast to the Russian Market, where we were earlier in the

If you’ve been to other markets in Cambodia, this is probably the most expensive. It seems kinda big, but it’s not impressive. If you’re short of time to check out others on your trip, this will do as it has everything but it’s not the biggest selection and definitely not the
With market inside. You can buy everything from clothes, gold and food inside. Dont know if its possible to see it from the high somewhere, but could be interesting.

Central market is easy to get to by tuk-tuk. once there it is big. you can get anything from motorcycle tyres to seafood. the food section is scary by western health standards but quite interesting. the sellers are not pushy like in Bali or Malaysia.

Wow these markets are one of the best I have ever been to. Lots of everything and great prices. If you bargain and they let you walk away you are to low. Usually go about half n see what happens. Some will give you sad faces but just a put on. Just awesome to walk around.

Iconic architecture. Shirts, souvenirs, electrical goods, gems & silver are available. If you are planning to buy silver, do ensure you do your homework. Outside the market, plenty of shops and restaurants as well. Suggest to spend couple of hours if you are planning to buy
Absolutely worth the visit. You will find what you are looking for. We enjoyed it more than Vietnam.
As far as markets go, compared to the size of the market, there was a surprising lack of goods on sale. If you have the chance to visit other large markets in Southeast Asia, give this a pass.

The central market is a very big and busy place that sells everything you can think of: jewellery, house hold, flowers, food (fresh and cooked), ornaments, clothes, shoes and "branded" items. You can choose to donate in the charity box at the entrance (a lot of people had put

Very large and extensive indoor market with items ranging from jewelry to T-shirts but I found the most interesting parts to be housewares, foods, and observing the seamstresses and hairdressers. And the florists displays are amazing. Certainly worth a look but don’t go planning

It's a pretty large complex with shops inside and outside selling similar things. Definitely haggle if you can. I found that they definitely sell a lot of stuff at least 50% cheaper than what I saw in duty free. Basically a place to purchase all your souvenir needs.

If you’ve got an hour or two the Central Market is a great place to wander through. The central atrium is dedicated to jewellery but the numerous wings and well stocked alleys host a variety of tourist gifts to fresh seafood and a cacophony of aromatic delights. 100 riel for

We have been to plenty of markets in Asia and were very surprised at how organised this market is. It’s split up into men’s, women’s and kid clothing, shoes, electronic, food and anything else you can think of. It was very relaxing walking around. Most visit.

We were impressed with this market, providing more space and variety of goods than most markets we have seen. We particularly enjoyed the food market displaying a wide variety of fruits and seafood amongst other things. Well worth a visit if you enjoy shopping and bargaining.

A big market selling comprehensive items. Clothings, household, IT stuff, jewelleries, watches, food, fruits.. and many more. Prices in Phnom Penh is more generally higher than Siem Reap. So you need to do some bargaining. The sellers are not pushy, which makes shopping there a

Wandered through the Central market as part of a day plan during my stay in Phnom Penh. Not the nicest or most exciting market I have visited in Southeast Asia but still worth a visit. Fairly fun to walk through the produce/food section to see the fresh catch of the day and grab

Because of this market has become a tourist spot, the price seems very expensive compare to other local markets. I experienced that most sellers there like to start with a very high offer price if you don't know how to negotiate well, you might be over charged.

Must visit this market for local shopping. Electronics, leather, jewellery, toys, cloths, household items. Make sure you bargain a lot and Must carry US$. Stay vigilant as it can be little crowded otherwise it’s absolutely safe.

Central Market is huge, and very accessible. It's rather neatly organised, which makes visiting each stall in the market easy. There's plenty of things being sold, so you will definitely be able to find something to bring back home.

Our family of four (two teenagers) enjoyed this market. Similar to other markets we’ve visited in SE Asia. More interesting than the Russian Market, little hassling and generally nice vendors. We found some amazing soup at a stall for a bargain and some delicious smoothies. Easy
If you like markets, this is for you. The central market is quite large and spills from its dome out. There is everything you could imagine, from food, to electronics, clothing and jewelry.
Some decent clothes to be found..nice and friendly with no pressure tactics. Bargaining a must Went to Russian market but nothing much there that was different. Suggest just come here

We loved this market. But its is so busy and kind of stressful (they are fairly aggressive), so I would give myself a day or so to get a bit familiar with Phnom Phen before I would go there. Make sure you know what you are buying and if possible a street price of theses goods

Not at all what we expected, underwhelmed big time. Clothes are a no no here, you're better off shopping for clothes in Bangkok. The exact same ladies top that can be had for 100 baht at Platinum Mall in BKK was at US$ 10 asking price here. Ladies pants that would go for 250-300

Central Market is a dome shaped building in the centre surrounded by extensions of stalls all around it. Besides wet market, many stalls selling semi precious and fake stones jewelry, imitation watches, clothing, household wares, shoes and many others can be found here.
Walking distance from my hotel. I have purchased fruit, household items, flowers, jewelry and had a watch band and the Chrystal replaced in very short period of time.
Good for t-shirts, trinkets, inexpensive clothes, and watches and jewelry of uncertain quality. We arrived just a little before 5pm on a Saturday, and a lot of the shops were closed or closing.

There's a central food area where you can sit down for a bowl of noodles for 7000 KHR ($1.75 USD approx.) Beware the wet market area, it sure smells of seafood and can be unbearable. I smelled it in my hair all day. There's a large area under the dome with lots of jewellery.

We visited this market on an afternoon where it had not a lot of clients. Clothes, silverware, electronic gadgets, toys, flowers, fish - the usual things. The building is nice - high ceilings which provides a good airy room climate.

Its a very busy market so be prepared for the hustle and bustle of a big market. The place offers wide variety of things (clothes, flower, grocery, bag etc). You must be extremely good at bargaining otherwise you would end paying 5-7 times more than the actual price.Siem Reap

This market offers the standard selection of tourist souvenirs and clothing that you will find in other markets in Cambodia. What sets this market aside is: 1. It is located in a specially designed building which was built and funded by the French. The central ceiling is very

I didn’t actually buy anything from the market, but just went to visit as it was very close to my hotel. It is loud, busy and if you are going to buy anything prepare to haggle and bargain for a good price!
Worth a visit! Full of any and everything, if you can't get there you'll not get it anywhere! Quite a maze, I'm still not sure if I managed to get all round it!

Anything you are looking for, you will find it in here. Loads of merchandise. What I really enjoyed and appreciated was that it was not crazy crowded and all the venders we encountered were very kind and professional and absolutely not pushy or aggressive. Also liked that most

Under cover helps to keep out of the heat. A huge collection of semi precious stone jewellery dealers. The usual tee shirts, clothes, bags stalls. Frenetic local eatery on the north side if you want real local food. Easy access from tuk tuk

Excellent pricing at this market. Much better than mall prices. Bring lots of American one dollar bills and bargain for what you want. There are some good knock offs and some cheesy ones but they all appear to be priced the same. Check products inside and out. Don’t pay what

Local goods, souvenirs, fresh fish, meats, jewelry and accessories... everything can be found in one place. You need to haggle, but the sellers are not pushy. No air conditioner but ceiling to minimize the heat. The place is kept clean as well.

We visited the central market and the nice surprise we got was that it was nice and cool inside. The vendors were not pushy and you could see a lot of different articles. From gold and silver to fresh fish and fruits. Of course there were also things that were only tourists
Mostly set up with items for tourists and you'll need to haggle to get appropriate prices. The building it is set in is lovely and overall stall holders are pleasant to interact with.
Recommended - cool Architecture, many vendors, don’t hesitate to negotiate, they can usually reduce price in half.
Quite large and a lot to see, the also tend to group similar stalls together which is good to compare.
If you want to get lost, buy anything and everything, change money, eat, and be amazed this is the place for you. It's like a massive maze. VERY interesting.

Housing in a incredible Art Deco dome built by the French during their days running Indochina, the Central Market is worth a trip just to admire the architecture alone. However it provides a varied outlet for your tourist $ with everything from jewellery (inexpensive “Rolex”

We loved this market better than the Russian Market. You could get lost here it is so big. A feature is a large covered central building that gives a bit more open space. Prices are very cheap, but stuff is below the quality desired by most people. The market exists for the

If you want to buy tourist trinkets or fabrics or faux designer bags then this is for you! Easily found, Don't eat there though ... I don't think the hygiene standards of cambodian street food are on a par with Vietnam or Malaysia
this is local cambodia market selling varitey of stuffs such as jewelry, watch, clothes, foods and fruits, need to bargain price when you are there, otherwise you might need to pay higher price
Not a lot of high pressure sales. Prices are good. Good location with food. Lots of selection. Recommend this when visit pnh

Really it’s a wonderful structural construction built in 1937 and renovated in 2011. Such a beautiful arrangement of rows of shops, stalls and kiosk. If you want to buy, you can find everything, and if not, a short visit is fine
We went there with expectations but there were really nothing to buy. Very warm inside and most of the items on display is just crap.

Although there were a number of negative reviews of this place i still went to visit it and was pleasantly surprised. They have hundreds of shops dealing in clothing, souvenirs, jewellery and food. Prices are very fair and you should still bargain. The shopkeepers are also
Wanting to look for souveniers, staffs before leaving? Authentic taste of cambodian food? You might want to try here in central market.
It is similar to the Chatuchak market in Thailand. It sells elephant pants, fake watches, bags and shoes. I enjoyed the market section seeing the live seafood and daringly tried the street food.
Great experience, must try the giant grilled squid, lots of different traditional dishes, fresh fruit and vegetables, avocado smoothie, eat fresh mango!! Beautiful photos by the flowers ;)

This is a huge sprawling complex with hundreds of stalls selling gems, bags, all manners of clothing, textile, food, shoes and everything under the sun. It is also a market selling meat, fish, veg and flowers. You can even wash your hair here! Good for tourists! Having visited

This place has just about EVERYTHING! Go early and see the livestock being prepared for busy shoppers stocking up the day's or week's groceries. Frogs, fish, meat and all manner of spices and vegetables can be found here. Aside from the typical Asian wet market section, this
Everyone will find something here. They have all the new clothes as you imagine. You can haggle down the price as well. Ladies this if definitely for you.

The Central market which was built in the 1930s is a circular building with arms containing market stores selling clothing electrical jewelry and more clothing. My main area I freaked out the food section this was a culinary explosion of smells colors and vibrancy. There is a

This huge sprawling market has just about everything you could want.Be streetwise take or buy a fan to keep you cool as you wind thru the hundreds of stalls. Probably a great way not to miss anything is start on the outside, only look at things you are keen on buying otherwise

It’s a very nice and old building , but not much art in it ! This place is in door but have no air con , so it’s not a good place to take The young children to ! They have a lot of fake watches , fake bages , low quality of silver which they look good only ! If you wish to

Surprisingly nice and clean market a lot of ckothing shops and gems and jewelry was hoping more options for food seems like most of the stalls sells the same soup items but everything was great experience.
Love markets with all sorts and just watching the locals do their business and for us tourists to buy souvenirs, great.

This was an interesting experience. There are lots of any thing you want all fake goods. The shop keepers don't harass you which is nice. Plenty of things if you want a Bargain. The food area is amazing lots of livestock chickens and fish so very fresh Well worth a visit
Central Market was not too bad if you just exploring the place but do not have high expectations because we found most the stalls were selling th same thing. We spent only about 30 mins there

Can find most anything in the Central Market. It is not remarkable just an adequate place to find most usable items one needs to resupply long travel excursions. Cloths etc. Was hot! Plenty of restaurants near by and transportation requirements if not walking.

A lot of markets in Phomn Pehn are geared up for the locals but here you will find allsorts. No pressure selling and worth haggling as the price they say is not the price you pay. Authentic and western all under 1 roof. The jewellery is defiantly worth looking at as they have
It's a market what can I say it sells tourist stuff. Big jewellery area in the middle. Wouldn't go out of my way to visit

If you really want to shop here, you need lots of time to wade through the many stalls. Bought a few simple souvenir t-shirts for USD 2 each. Our best buy was a full formal suit for my 11 yo which only cost USD38. Polo shirts and such were not worth the price for the quality.

The shopping here is fantastic. You will find anything you want and things you didn’t know you wanted. From electronics to shoes, clothes to souvenirs it has everything. It’s spacious and worth a few visits to check out each part. The stall owners are happy to haggle to a

We were surprised how easy it was to walk around - plenty of space and the food areas at the edge provided good choices for lunch. The central area - designed for tourists was not our interest but generally is worth wandering around if you have time. For us the Russian market

We've been in and out of several of the big central markets still in operation in SE-Asia. Mostly they have slid into the tourist trap category, full of cheap plastic tat and hawkers pushing what could only be described as rubbish. The Phnom Penh Central markets are better than
A building with many stalls selling stuff. Nothing more, nothing less. Not cheap, not special, just that.
Nice to visit ... but the merchant seem to think that all barangs are idiots willing to pay triple the price , so be prepare to haggle or forget it .

The building has been restored and is an interesting relic of the French era. The market is laid out in zones according to the type of merchandise sold. However I found it a bit soulless and overpriced as compared to elsewhere. I much preferred the Russian Market for a more
One of the many markets in Phnom Penh. As it is the „central market“ it is more touristic than the others. Sellers are quiet annoying towards foreigners...

Are you looking for a new wardrobe, shoes, maybe a new watch or jewelry? But also want to pick up a souvenir and some fresh fruit or fish whilst nearly being run over by a scooter INSIDE the market? Well then the Central Market is the place for you! You can find almost

Central market is one of all the market in Phnom Penh that sell many kind of products with good quality. There are many foreign visitors there. Many things are there such as food, electronic stuffs, clothes, souvenirs,etc. When you visit there you'll see. Looking forward to see

What a massive dome! Built by the French in the 1930's? The markets seem to have everything, we were told to avoid buying any of the silver jewellery (as it will turn black about a week after purchase) but very interesting to walk around and take in the sights sounds and smells.
The layout of this place ma it easier for you to shop around. They have already categorized everything. You could see a lot local food from here especially like those insect and weird stuff.

I was staying fairly close by, so took a short tuk tuk ride over to check it out. I needed a few t shirts and found some real nice ones for just a few bucks. Lots of knock offs similar to markets in Thailand, but still relatively good quality!

If you've been to Chatuchak in Bangkok, you can skip this. But if you've too much time or too much money, or if you really just wanna buy something like low quality, fake or perhaps fake stuff such as shoes, watches, scarfs, hats, then come. Like what many have said, and like
Great market for casual clothes. Remember to bargain but don't try and screw them down too much. They are trying to make a living.

A big, largely indoor, market that didn't feel too cramped when walking around. Unlike in some places, I didn't get harrassed by stall holders as I wandered around and there was a wider selection than in some markets - it wasn't just full of tourist tat!
Just another Asian market. All the same stuff you see at any other. If you are staying nearby it’s worth a look. Otherwise don’t bother

Well designed funky market with all the souvenirs and trinkets you could want for family and friends back home. Very untidy stalls and lanes on the way in but attractive and interesting once you're inside.

Central market is a very busy hustle bustle place. There is not much you cannot find here. As you walk your way around and through stop for a meal in the food market. It is fresh, relatively cheap and tasty... what ever you decide upon. My favourite is the pork noodle soup.

Beautiful art deco building that houses this market. Well organised, with each of the 4 wings organised into selling items closely related to each other. It's good, but it feels like it's for tourists here - prefer the Russian Market.
Found everything we needed for gifts to family and friends. Decent prices and wide variety of goods. Many of them seem to be couterfact products so be careful with branded items.

Having been in Siem Reap for a week Phnom Penh feels like a violent assault on the senses. It is a nauseating place and this market didn’t offer any reprieve or have unique craft items for sale (all same same t-shirts, paintings, sculptures). I have yet to visit a nightmarket

How can you miss the market in Cambodia Capital. Get there with a kmer tuk tuk and your friendly driver that will help you in dealing with the vendors. Walk slowly, smell, feel and buy and bargain. It is the master way to know this marvellous people. So the market is a a place
offer various items from gem stones to clothes and touristy item such as fridge magnets to key chains

A busy market not far off the tourist strip. Interesting building with the inside being a labyrinth of “jewelry” stalls and copy watches. As you delve further away from the center of the building a more interesting world developes into a typical Asian market where most anything

You can find everything here. Stalls are friendly to buy from, harder to bargain with than the Russian Market but still easy. You can also find electronics which is useful say if you need more camera memory cards! We also needed a black pen which turns out is very hard to find,

I read a lot of good words about this place before I came, but was a bit let down after visiting it. It was more like a touristic place than a genuine market. The stalls were quite closely packed with only a narrow path for many visitors. The things sold here do come in a

Visited with my wife. Very crowded, hot, sticky and sweaty!! Interesting place to visit, especially the central area which was not so overwhelming. All the other stalls pretty much selling the same goods. Sellers happy to haggle, but you still pay tourist prices.

If you go take your patience with you and maybe your appetite. The central market is huge and you should also have some patience. Get yourself an iced latte and find the food after shopping. I walked around the outside and entered where the jewelry stalls are. Small aisles

The location is great and being in a building it’s better when it rains. They’re is literally everything sold there and the prices can be really reasonable! However, there are much better markets in Asia and people can be funny with you if you don’t buy certain things. Dress in
We preferred this market due to it being more roomy with plenty of light, there are lots of indoor or outdoor stalls.

The building is quite splendid...a lovely piece of Asian Architecture and worth a look....but..... If you have travelled anywhere at all in south east asia, the first thing that strikes you is "this exactly the same Chinese rubbish I saw in the last country". Mostly it is full
Fascinating to walk through the market. To view Cambodians living and working. It’s OK to bargain...
google:
Nice place to buy shoes, fake watches, clothes for males/females. Good collections in crockery. Good items from local manufacturers. They do offer bargains for anything between 30% to 50% of the price on offer. Be careful and take the best deal available, do compare with multiple vendors and then only buy.

Good place overall.
Nice clothes even for big man. Friendly shop owner and cheap prices. Not so stinky like the Russian Market. open and not hot inside. Nice place.

They sell all kind of goods here - from souvenirs through clothes to the fresh fruits or fish. It is a large area mostly shaded. The   corridors are more spacious than at other markets we have visited - I guess once feel more freedom to move and look around. However the prices are touristic even if you haggle.

This is a great place to buy cheap clothes, jewellery, fresh produce, flowers, souvenirs and a lot more. You can get plenty of imitation products. Be ready to bargain as they'll always quote high if you're a tourist. It's housed in an old …

here is too crowded so I can hardly take pictures with the camera, because it needs to be careful. My lodging near the location is only 2km from the riverside. unique building not like the market in general. and many gold sellers and accessories diamonds. outside the market a lot of street food.

Central Market is where it's at!! We tried three different stalls with 4 different meals , the favourite being the stir friend rice noodle drops with egg and meat. Pretty good value for $2 a plate.. space is tight and pretty busy at lunch …

Very full of vendors, you could feel the business. But as I said about Israel, far too many people selling, to the ratio of people buying. Supply and demand is very off balance, there are vendors soooo! desperate for money, they get angry …

My favorite part of the market, like many of the markets in Southeast Asia, is the carts with fresh fruit juice, pancakes with fruit and various street food.  There are also the typical tourist items AND, most important, the local market …

text.wiki:
Choeung Ek (Khmer: ជើងឯក  [cəəŋ aek]) is the site of a former orchard and mass grave of victims of the Khmer Rouge – killed between 1975 and 1979 – in Dangkao Section, Phnom Penh, Cambodia, about 17 kilometres (11 mi) south of the Phnom Penh city centre. It is the best-known of the sites known as The Killing Fields, where the Khmer Rouge regime executed over one million people between 1975 and 1979.


== Description ==
Mass graves containing 8,895 bodies were discovered at Choeung Ek after the fall of the Khmer Rouge regime. Many of the dead were former political prisoners who were kept by the Khmer Rouge in their Tuol Sleng detention center and in other Cambodian detention centers.
Today, Choeung Ek is a memorial, marked by a Buddhist stupa. The stupa has acrylic glass sides and is filled with more than 5,000 human skulls. Some of the lower levels are opened during the day so that the skulls can be seen directly. Many have been shattered or smashed in.
Tourists are encouraged by the Cambodian government to visit Choeung Ek. Apart from the stupa, there are pits from which the bodies were exhumed. Human bones still litter the site.
On May 3, 2005, the Municipality of Phnom Penh announced that they had entered into a 30-year agreement with JC Royal Co. to develop the memorial at Choeung Ek.  As part of the agreement, they are not to disturb the remains still present in the field.


== In popular culture ==
The film The Killing Fields is a dramatised portrayal of events like those that took place at Choeung Ek.

text.wiki:
The Fall of Phnom Penh was the capture of Phnom Penh, the capital of the Khmer Republic, by the Khmer Rouge on 17 April 1975, effectively ending the Cambodian Civil War. At the beginning of April 1975, Phnom Penh, one of the last remaining strongholds of the Khmer Republic, was surrounded by the Khmer Rouge and totally dependent on aerial resupply through Pochentong Airport. With a Khmer Rouge victory imminent, the US government evacuated US nationals and allied Cambodians on 12 April 1975. On 17 April the Khmer Republic government evacuated the city, intending to establish a new government center close to the Thai border to continue resistance. Later that day the last defences around Phnom Penh were overrun, and the Khmer Rouge occupied Phnom Penh.
Captured Khmer Republic forces were taken to the Olympic Stadium where they were executed, while senior government and military leaders were forced to write confessions prior to their executions. The Khmer Rouge ordered the evacuation of Phnom Penh, emptying the city except for expatriates who took refuge in the French Embassy until 30 April when they were transported to Thailand.


== Background ==
At the beginning of 1975 the Khmer Republic, a United States-supported military government, controlled only the Phnom Penh area and a string of towns along the Mekong River that provided the crucial supply route for food and munitions coming upriver from South Vietnam. As part of their 1975 dry season offensive, rather than renewing their frontal attacks on Phnom Penh, the Khmer Rouge set out to cut the crucial Mekong supply route. On 12 January 1975 the Khmer Rouge attacked Neak Luong, a key Khmer National Armed Forces (FANK) defensive outpost on the Mekong. On 27 January, seven vessels limped into Phnom Penh, the survivors of a 16-ship convoy that had come under attack during the 100 kilometres (62 mi) journey from the South Vietnamese border. On 3 February a convoy heading downriver hit naval mines laid by the Khmer Rouge at Phú Mỹ, approximately 74 kilometres (46 mi) from Phnom Penh. The Khmer National Navy (MNK) had mine-sweeping capability, but due to the Khmer Rouge control of the riverbanks mine-sweeping was impossible or, at best, extremely costly. The MNK had lost a quarter of its ships, and 70 percent of its sailors had been killed or wounded.By 17 February, the Khmer Republic abandoned attempts to reopen the Mekong supply line; all subsequent supplies for Phnom Penh would have to come in by air to Pochentong Airport. The United States quickly mobilised an airlift of food, fuel and ammunition into Phnom Penh, but as US support for the Khmer Republic was limited by the Case–Church Amendment, BirdAir, a company under contract to the US Government, controlled the airlift with a mixed fleet of C-130 and DC-8 planes, flying 20 times a day into Pochentong from U-Tapao Royal Thai Navy Airfield.On 5 March, Khmer Rouge artillery at Toul Leap (11.574°N 104.757°E﻿ / 11.574; 104.757), north-west of Phnom Penh, shelled Pochentong Airport, but FANK troops recaptured Toul Leap on 15 March and ended the shelling. Khmer Rouge forces continued to close in to the north and west of the city and were soon able to fire on Pochentong again. On 22 March rockets hit two supply aircraft, forcing the US Embassy to announce on 23 March a suspension of the airlift until the security situation improved. The Embassy, realizing that the Khmer Republic would soon collapse without supplies, reversed the suspension on 24 March and increased the number of aircraft available for the airlift. The hope among the Khmer Government and the Embassy was that the Khmer Rouge offensive could be held back until the start of the rainy season in May when fighting typically abated.


== Offensive ==


=== Late March ===
By late March the FANK maintained a defensive perimeter some 15 kilometres (9.3 mi) from central Phnom Penh. In the northwest, the 7th Division was in an increasingly difficult position, its front had been cut in several places, particularly in the region of Toul Leap which had changed hands several times. The 3rd Division, located on Route 4 in the vicinity of Bek Chan (11.51°N 104.748°E﻿ / 11.51; 104.748), some 10 kilometres (6.2 mi) west of Pochentong was cut off from its own command post at Kompong Speu.In the south, the 1st Division handled the defense, along with the 15th Brigade of Brigadier General Lon Non; it was the calmest part of the front at that time. In the region of Takhmau, Route 1 and the Bassac River, the 1st Division was subject to continued Khmer Rouge pressure. East of the capital were the Parachute Brigade and the troops of the Phnom Penh Military Region. The MNK naval base on the Chrouy Changvar peninsula (11.583°N 104.916°E﻿ / 11.583; 104.916) and the Khmer Air Force (KAF) base at Pochentong were defended by their own forces. The key position of Neak Luong on the east bank of the Mekong was completely isolated. The KAF and the MNK were overstretched and undersupplied and could not satisfy the demands of the FANK. The general logistic situation for FANK was increasingly critical and the resupply of ammunition for the infantry could only be carried out sporadically.


=== 1 April ===
Premier Lon Nol resigned on 1 April. The departure ceremony at the Chamcar Mon Palace was attended by Khmer only, the diplomatic corps having not been invited. From the grounds of Chamcar Mon, helicopters took Lon Nol, his family and party to Pochentong, where Lon Nol met US Ambassador John Gunther Dean before boarding an Air Cambodge flight to U-Tapao in Thailand and into exile. Saukam Khoy became acting President and it was hoped that with Lon Nol's departure peace negotiations could progress.The rapidly worsening situation of March was capped on the night of 1 April by the fall of Neak Luong, despite ferocious resistance and following a three-month siege. This development opened the southern approach to the capital and freed up 6000 Khmer Rouge soldiers to join the forces besieging Phnom Penh. The capture of six 105-mm howitzers at Neak Luong was a further menace to the capital.


=== 2–11 April ===
From 3–4 April all FANK positions on Route 1 above Neak Luong held by the FANK 1st Division fell one after the other, any reinforcement, whether by road or by the Mekong, was impossible. North of the capital, in the 7th Division area, Khmer Rouge attacks came daily and despite regular air support, there was no improvement in the situation there. Several counterattacks by FANK, carried out to retake lost positions, were unsuccessful. The losses suffered by the 1st Division grew each day and the evacuation of its sick and wounded by helicopter was no longer possible. The last reserves of the high command, constituted by hastily taking the battalions of the former Provincial Guard, were rushed to the north, only to be completely dispersed by the Khmer Rouge after several hours of combat. A great breach was opened in the northern defenses; there was not hope of closing it. To the west, the troops of Brigadier General Chantaraingsei's 3rd Division, despite reinforcements, were unable to join with their own elements at Kompong Speu and to retake the position at Toul Leap. A computation error which caused FANK artillery fire to land on 3rd Division elements during this operation had a bad effect on the unit's morale.Throughout this period civilian refugees fled toward the capital from all directions. The authorities, both civil and military, were swamped and no one knew where to lodge them. Schools, pagodas and public gardens were occupied by these refugees and there was no way for the authorities to determine who was friend and who was Khmer Rouge.On 11 April in Peking the US Government requested the immediate return of Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the figurehead leader of the National United Front of Kampuchea (FUNK), to Phnom Penh. Sihanouk rejected the request the following morning.


=== 12 April ===

With the situation worsening in Phnom Penh, on 12 April the US Embassy initiated Operation Eagle Pull, the evacuation of all US personnel. Ambassador Dean invited the members of the Government to be evacuated, but all refused except for acting President Saukham Khoy, who left without telling his fellow leaders. The evacuation came as a shock to many in the Khmer Republic leadership, because not only Phnom Penh but almost all provincial capitals (except those in the east occupied by the North Vietnamese) were in the hands of the government, packed with millions of refugees. Estimates put the population under government control at six million, and those under Khmer Rouge control at one million.At 08:30, the Council of Ministers met in the office of Prime Minister Long Boret. It was decided that a general assembly should be convoked, consisting of the highest functionaries and military leaders. From 14:00 the general assembly sat in the Chamcar Mon Palace. It finally adopted a unanimous resolution asking for the transfer of power to the military and condemning Saukham Khoy for not handing over his office in a legitimate way. At 23:00 the general assembly elected the members of the Supreme Committee: Lieutenant general Sak Sutsakhan, the FANK Chief of Staff, Major General Thongvan Fanmuong, MNK Rear admiral Vong Sarendy, KAF commander Brigadier general Ea Chhong, Long Boret, Hang Thun Hak, Vice Prime Minister and Op Kim Ang: representative of the Social Republican Party.The military situation had deteriorated sharply during the day. In the north the defensive line was cut at several points by the Khmer Rouge, in spite of the fierce resistance by FANK units. Pochentong Airport was in imminent danger of being taken; the small military airport of Mean Chey had to be designated as an emergency landing place for the planes and helicopters bringing ammunition and supplies.


=== 13–16 April ===
 
13 April was the Cambodian New Year and the Khmer Rouge continued to bombard Phnom Penh. At 09:00 the Supreme Committee had its first session and unanimously elected Sak Sutsakhan president, becoming both the head of the government and interim Chief of State. Sak decided to make a last peace offer to Prince Sihanouk, transferring the Republic and its armed forces to him, but not surrendering to the Khmer Rouge. Late that night Sak called a meeting of the Council of Ministers, this time consisting of both the Supreme Committee and the Cabinet, made decisions including certain political and military measures, channeling the ever increasing stream of refugees into schools, pagodas, their feeding, the reshuffling of the cabinet, reinforcing the troops in Phnom Penh by flying in a few battalions from different provinces through the Mean Chey airport and the formation of an Ad Hoc Committee chaired by Long Boret to prepare peace overtures for either Prince Sihanouk or the Khmer Rouge.On 14 April the military situation was becoming increasingly precarious. That morning the Cabinet met at Sak's office at the General Staff Headquarters (11.567°N 104.925°E﻿ / 11.567; 104.925). At 10:25 a KAF pilot dropped four 250-pound bombs from his T-28 fighter bomber. Two of the bombs exploded about 20 yards (18 m) from Sak's office killing seven officers and NCOs and wounded twenty others. Sak declared a 24-hour curfew and that the battle would continue. That afternoon Takhmau, the capital of Kandal Province, 11 kilometres (6.8 mi) south of Phnom Penh fell to the Khmer Rouge. The loss of this town, a key point in the FANK defense perimeter, had a demoralizing effect. Several counterattacks were initiated but to no avail. Soon a fierce battle was in progress in the southern suburbs. The U.S. aerial resupply into Pochentong was completely halted.The 15th began with the Khmer Rouge pressing in from north and west. Pochentong and the dike running east/west to the north of Phnom Penh, both of which formed the last ring of defense around the capital, were overrun by Khmer Rouge assaults. The intervention of the Parachute Brigade, brought back from the east of the Mekong, had no effect on the situation to the west of the capital. The brigade tried to move west, but was only able to get 6 kilometres (3.7 mi) down Route 4. Meanwhile, refugees continued to pour into the city.

On 16 April, the morning Cabinet meeting was devoted entirely to the mechanics of sending a peace offer to Peking as quickly as possible. Long Boret drafted the offer calling for an immediate ceasefire and a transfer of power to FUNK. The offer was sent to Peking via the Red Cross and the Agence France-Presse. The military situation was becoming worse, the Shell oil depot (11.607°N 104.917°E﻿ / 11.607; 104.917) north of the city was set ablaze by gunfire, while fire swept shacks to the south of the city. All afternoon the Cabinet waited for the answer from Peking. By 23:00 an answer had still not arrived and the Cabinet realized that the Khmer Rouge did not want to accept the offer. Meanwhile, the Khmer Rouge had occupied the east bank of the Mekong following the withdrawal of the Parachute Brigade, while General Dien Del’s 2nd Division held the Monivong Bridge.KAF T-28Ds flew their last combat sortie by bombing the KAF control centre and hangars at Pochentong upon its capture by the Khmer Rouge. After virtually expending their ordnance reserves, 97 KAF aircraft escaped from airbases and auxiliary airfields throughout Cambodia, with a small number of civilian dependents on board, to safe havens in neighbouring Thailand.


=== 17 April ===

At 02:00 on 17 April the Cabinet agreed that, as its peace offer had not been accepted, it would move the Cabinet, the Supreme Committee and even members of the Assembly from Phnom Penh to the north to the capital of Oddar Meanchey Province on the Thai border in order to continue resistance from there. The only way to leave the capital was by helicopter. At 04:00 the members of the Government met in the garden in front of the Wat Botum Vaddey (11.559°N 104.932°E﻿ / 11.559; 104.932) for evacuation, but the helicopters did not show up. Dawn was breaking over the eastern horizon. The Government members returned to Premier Long Boret's house at 05:30 and decided to resist to the death in Phnom Penh itself. After 06:00, the Minister of Information, Thong Lim Huong, brought a cable just arrived from Peking advising that the peace appeal had been rejected by Sihanouk. At the same time they branded the seven members of the Supreme Committee as chief traitors, in addition to the seven who had taken power in 1970.Heavy fighting had been taking place since 04:00 in the north of the city around the main power station (11.59°N 104.915°E﻿ / 11.59; 104.915). By dawn the firing ceased as the FANK forces gave way to the Khmer Rouge and retreated along Monivong Boulevard into the city center. Admiral Vong Sarendy had returned to the naval base which was under attack by the Khmer Rouge. He called Sak later advising that the base was surrounded and about to be overrun. As Khmer Rouge forces entered the command post Sarendy committed suicide.By 08:00 the rest of the Cabinet, the deputies and the senators left the session, leaving Long Boret and Sak. General Thach Reng arrived to plead with them to leave with him, as he still had his men of the Special Forces and seven UH-1 helicopters at his disposal at the Olympic Stadium. At approximately 08:30 Sak and his family boarded a helicopter and were flown out, as was KAF commander Ea Chhong. Meanwhile, Long Boret boarded another helicopter which failed to take off. Four helicopters flew to Kampong Thom to refuel, arriving at 09:30. Establishing radio contact with Phnom Penh, Sak learned that the Khmer Rouge had penetrated into the General Staff Headquarters. General Mey Sichan addressed the nation and the troops in Sak's name asking them to hoist the white flag as a sign of peace. Sak's helicopter arrived at Oddar Meanchey at 13:30, as the collapse of the Republic was imminent. Any chance of reestablishing the Government evaporated and the assembled officers decided to seek exile in Thailand.As the Khmer Rouge entered the capital, a small group of soldiers and armed students, styled as the MONATIO and led by Hem Keth Dara, began driving around the city welcoming the arrival of the Khmer Rouge. MONATIO was apparently a creation of Lon Non, in an attempt to share power with the Khmer Rouge. Initially tolerated by the Khmer Rouge, MONATIO members were later rounded up and executed.Several hours later the Khmer Rouge began entering central Phnom Penh from all directions and stationed themselves at the major crossroads where they disarmed FANK soldiers and collected weapons. The disarmed soldiers were then marched to the Olympic Stadium where they were later executed. The Khmer Rouge held a press conference at the Ministry of Information where a number of prisoners, including Lon Non and Hem Keth Dara, were being held. A car carrying Long Boret arrived and he joined the prisoners.After midday the Khmer Rouge ordered the evacuation of the city for three days, evicting expatriates and Cambodians from the Hotel Le Phnom which the Red Cross had sought to establish as a neutral zone, and emptying the city's hospitals which contained approximately 20,000 wounded who were unlikely to survive the walk to the countryside. Approximately 800 expatriates and 600 Cambodians took refuge at the French Embassy (11.583°N 104.916°E﻿ / 11.583; 104.916). At this time the Khmer Rouge military numbered only 68,000, with a further 14,000 party members. Elizabeth Becker asserts that lacking the numbers necessary to openly control Cambodia, emptying Phnom Penh of those of its population who were indifferent or openly hostile to them was essential for securing Khmer Rouge control.Koy Thuon, a Khmer Rouge deputy front commander, organized the "Committee for Wiping Out Enemies" at the Hotel Monorom (11.57°N 104.918°E﻿ / 11.57; 104.918). Its first action was to order the immediate execution of Lon Nol and other leading government figures. Captured FANK officers were taken to the Hotel Monoram to write their biographies and then to the Olympic Stadium, where they were executed.


== Aftermath ==
On the morning of 18 April, Sak and the remaining members of the Khmer Republic Government and assorted military personnel boarded a KAF C-123 and flew to U-Tapao and into exile. The same day the Khmer Rouge ordered all Cambodians in the French Embassy, other than women married to Frenchmen, to leave the Embassy or they would take it over; they rejected any right of asylum. Among those evicted was Prince Sisowath Sirik Matak, one of those responsible for the removal of Sihanouk from power in 1970 and who had been branded one of the seven original traitors marked for execution by the FUNK. Also evicted were Princess Mam Manivan Phanivong, one of Sihanouk's wives; Khy-Taing Lim, the Minister of Finance; and Loeung Nal, the Minister of Health.Long Boret was executed on the grounds of the Cercle Sportif in Phnom Penh (ironically now the location of the US Embassy) on or about 21 April. Khmer Rouge Radio subsequently reported that he had been beheaded but other reports indicate that he and Sisowath Sirik Matak were executed by firing squad or that he was shot in the kidney and left to suffer a slow death, while his family were executed by machine gun fire.Pol Pot arrived in a deserted Phnom Penh on 23 April. On 30 April the occupants of the French Embassy were loaded onto trucks and driven to the Thai border arriving four days later.The collapse of the Khmer Republic following the Fall of Phnom Penh allowed the Khmer Rouge to consolidate their control over Cambodia and begin the implementation of their agrarian socialism. Supporters of the Khmer Republic and the intelligentsia were killed, while the former urban population was used as forced labor in the countryside with many dying from physical abuse and malnutrition. This ultimately resulting in 1.5-2 million deaths during the Cambodian Genocide.The Khmer Rouge severed all contact with the outside world other than with its supporters, China and North Vietnam. With the Fall of Saigon on 30 April 1975 the Khmer Rouge demanded that all People's Army of Vietnam (PAVN) and Viet Cong forces leave their base areas in Cambodia, but the PAVN refused to leave certain areas which they claimed were Vietnamese territory. The PAVN also moved to take control of a number of islands formerly controlled by South Vietnam and other territory and islands contested between Vietnam and Cambodia. This led to a series of clashes between Vietnam and Cambodia on several islands in May 1975 and the seizure of foreign ships by the Khmer Rouge which triggered the Mayaguez incident. Clashes between Cambodia and Vietnam continued until August 1975. Relations between the two countries improved thereafter until early 1977 when the Kampuchean Revolutionary Army began attacking Vietnamese border provinces, killing hundreds of Vietnamese civilians; this eventually resulted in the Cambodian–Vietnamese War starting in December 1978.


== In popular culture ==
The Fall of Phnom Penh is depicted in the film The Killing Fields.

Strolled out to the market from our hotel and when we got there it really seemed like a bit of a waste of time. Nothing really special at all. You can get all of the stuff elsewhere in the local markets. They have a food court behind the main stage - but I dibn’t fancy eating
It’s not worth to visit market as they sale very cheap stuff. Huge stage has 1-2 performers but almost nil viewers. Don’t waste your time.
Nothing really to buy here. Waste of time strolling around. Tee shirts and other clothing items are mainly sold here. Many restaurants and bars in the area.not too crowded .

Visiting night markets across Asia, this one really didn’t impress me much. The food corner seemed interesting, especially as the seating area features no tables (people traditionally seat on the floor). Otherwise not much to see and do here.
Very interesting cultural experience which is worth doing if you want to see how the locals interact in the evening. We didn’t stay long but walked around and took some photos

Good place to experience as a local night market. Since it is river front open air market, the air is quite refreshing. Limited offer to shop, mostly clothes and some souvenirs, watches, shoes, etc..One section of the market is picnic like food court where you have to sit on the
No need to spend much time as it is food and inexpensive clothing but great to see how locals enjoy it. Open air rugs for eating.

Market was clothes and food and little else. We would have eaten there but stalls with chairs were full and we are a little on the wrong side of age to be comfortable hunkering down on the ground to eat, walked around for 10 minutes and left. Would recommend for food if you can

The night market was very underwhelming. Nothing special and quite disappointing. In comparison to Vietnam/ thailand and a very near neighbouring siem reap this is really nothing special. 7 years ago it was totally different. Clearly it's changed and not for the better.
Visites this place to get experience about local marjet. We did not buy anything but we got a nice walking around to see the people

Surely a great place to soak up local life. The food section in the back is particularly interesting. The market itself is lots of cheap wear and plenty of knock off merchandise. Still great to browse through the small corridors.
The Market was a small but clean and not supper crowded so was nice to stroll and able to take your time and see the stales. But product is very limited and food selection is also limited

We finished the things we wanted to do early, and while we were in the area anyway, we decided to come to the night market. We took a tuk tuk there from the main area, he wanted $2, we bargained for $1 and he said yes (but gave him $2 anyway cos we felt bad haha) The night
The food at the night market is delicious. All the shops sell the same menu. For muslims, they only have one Halal shops. It’s full of people everyday.

Plenty of bargains to be had at phnom pehns night market.Great way to meet the locals with many food stalls to the rear of the market.Was a band playing when I was there,plenty of SD stalls with clothes shoes etc.
If you have been to other night markets then would probably give this a miss, a lot of stalls ,some food places, alot less variety than siam reap markets,did not stay here long

This market is nice to walk around and had a good atmosphere. There was a stage with people singing on. It was a bit small. I felt safe walking around as a solo female traveller. There are lots of tuk tuk drivers at the entrance for you.

Worth spending an hour or so to browse around. Limited stalls with mainly clothes. Better value here than at Central or Russian markets and much friendlier stallholders. There is a food area with carpets to sit on mainly used by locals.
the market is nice, and is easy to find, nice lighting to find your way around. they offer a variety of local stuff as well as international goods. it was a nice to vist

Went to the Night Market expecting lots of stalls selling all sorts of ware but it's just kids carnival rides, overpriced at that. There is a convenience store, if you call this a market, selling a few clothes and everyday groceries.

Was impressed with the night market. You can buy different snacks or drinks from this place and people are friendly

If you want to kill some time ( and don’t value yours) go to these markets. It’s well below average compared to others of this type in Asia. Lots of locals, and some suspicious looking characters ( keep hold of your money and personal belongings) this place is the perfect

This night market is more cooler to shop than Russian market and smaller than central market. So you will find it more worth a visit here. There are food selling here too.
Good night market and fun to visit for shopping and eating. The new container night markets are more exciting and is where the locals and expats go.
Market here lacks the life n vitality n variety of Siem reap night markets . Somehow or other the buzz is missing。 Ok for first timers n those who haven't been to Siem reap first.

Worth a visit. Great deals to make on traditional souvenir stuff and clothes.. Just remeber ALWAYS be great at bargaining.

This place has so much to offer,music, food, drinks, clothes, accessories, shoes... The food is inexpensive and drinks are cheap!! The coconut ice cream comes highly recommended, 3 scoops of ice cream with tender coconut and a glass of coconut water!!! We loved the night market!!

I love a good Asian market but this is terrible. Tshirts and cheap toys you can get for better prices at the Russian or central markets. Food is ok but not worth going.

I found this market to be more expensive than both the central market and the russian market. There was not many people there.

The food was okay and a little cheap. They have a mat set up all over the ground where you can sit and hang out with your friends. You can do something like a "night picnic".

For me i didn't really find it attracting as i have nothing to do with night life But there were Pubs everywhere and many massage centres and bars and a bit less amount for food sellers and almost nothing else as far as i saw cuz we stayed there only for one night

This is a nice market that is more about clothing and wallets etc etc. It is used extensively by the local youth. Whilenitnis in the river tourist district, the tourists are watered down a lot here with locals so great atmosphere and if you have teenage kids they will love it

The part we went to was mainly food. There are stores selling many different type of food, with the most common offering different local dishes and rice. We bought some roasted pork which was fantastic, there were barbecue fishes and one store with leg of lamb for barbecue.

If you have some free time to kill. Why not take a short tour at nigh market. You can find variety of clothes, jewellery and some local food. This market is pretty small so don't put you expectations up. Do watch out, as it can be crowded.

Cheap and good quality food, loved the omelettes. Lots of different choices and a good atmosphere with friendly service

Nice deals...one has to bargain a lot...good stuff... good night Life scene at street 130 , 136.. women shopping Paradise. Men limited choice..😀

Night markets are usually exciting vibrant places. This was basically a clothes market with little interest for the tourist.
It's "just" one of those night markets, nothing exceptional about it. Ok for a walk. Lots of clothing stuff on sale. I found the food section most interesting

Nothing to recommend it. Many small stalls selling cheap goods and copies. A cramped and busy market.

If you have seen the Russian or central market you don't REALY need to come here, the only difference is the night. Fresh food and live music available I think in about 1 hour you have seen everything. Not the biggest market in Asia. I liked it but you don't miss anything

You can come here for halal food and beside this stall have coconuts ais cream..you should came here to try.
A small market but no push or pressure to purchase .. you can walk freely through the market without being harassed. Try the coconut ice cream in the food area.. comes with a free coconut water..

Since it's the market, the quality of the food is just ok. It is nice place to hangout tho since they have pretty space area for you to stay for long time. The fried noodle and ice cream there are good. I like chocolate taste with some coconut and peanut on top. It's also nice

It is a nice market to visit but quite small! I had really good cheap food there and it was nice to see it but nothing special! I also must say I was on nicer Night markets before in Cambodia!

This is a horrible market, nothing decent at all. Rows of cheap copied clothes, bags and underwear fit for the bin. The area is dimly lit and doesn't feel safe at all, do not go here.

This is not the best place to buy stuffs. But a good place to have a feel of a night market here. There are things to see and there's a big stage where there are performances too.
Only open on weekend nights this place was packed with locals. Is interesting to walk through and see the local food etc, but nothing really for the general tourist here.

Low quality of goods, vert cheep, street food.... At the oposite side a good restrain exists and an Italian stile food complex

Similar to those stuff you could get from Central/Russian market. Clothes, handicrafts, bags. Not a good place for a visit during rainy season

Come here in night hours. Life music, cheap clothes and a lot of cheap local junk food. This is great place to start communications with locals . Just take some food here and stard relaxing :)
