This place is mainly for tourists, so you get your typical tourist stuff there (shirts, shoes, souvenirs, etc.). It also has a place to get some good street food, where also the locals sit on carpets on the ground and eat.

The place offers a range of Khmer and western dishes to try. The market offers a lot of stuff to buy the major ones being the apparel and souvenirs. When I went there, there was some local song and dance events going on at the centre stage.

A small market selling mainly clothes but if you go to the back you can get some really great cheap food. We had a really good chicken curry with noodles for €1.75, pork skewers for 50 cents each and coconut ice cream, served in a coconut for €1.25 you sit on mats to eat the

The stalls here offer cheap clothes and souvenir but there are limited choices and rather small, catered more to locals. We covered the entire night market in just less than 30 minutes. But the typical massive Bangkok or Vietnam night markets. The surrounding places have good
The market itself is nice but not amazing. The cool part is getting some food at the back of the market, sitting on mats with locals and people watching. The coconut ice cream makes a great dessert!

This market is not too bad but no big deal. Although it's not very crowded or loud it's a little shy on quality stuff. My favorites are the $2.50 Ray Ban knock offs, silk scarfes and flip flops. If you're a big boy over a N.American size 48 you really have to hunt for clothing

A good place to shop and have dinner all fresco - sitting down like a picnic. If you have knee problems , you can find some hawkers with tables and chairs. Noodles. Fruit juices, sugar can water, local salads and lots more..as for shopping you can get clothes and house hold

This night market is quite small and seems to be geared mainly to locals, with stalls selling mostly clothes. We have been every night of our stay in Phnom Penh for dinner as the food is cheap and it has a nice atmosphere. There are only a few stalls, located behind the stage,
The only night market to be shut and we checked it would be open and it wasn't. We met people who had been and they said it was one of the cheaper night markets but we did not get to find out! ☹️

This is a night market that has stores selling quite a variety of items ranging from t-shirts to slippers and food. It isn't huge, in fact, if you do not stop at any of the stores, you'd probably be done with this night market within 10 minutes. Towards the back of the night

Wow! This place is huge and has many many things to buy. All very cheap and they accept American dollars, and preferred it to other currencies. Cheap jewelry especially the jade. Need much time to shop here or bring a list. You get overwhelm easily. And it is so humid and hot.

I'm generally not a fan of night markets (too crowded, too loud, too stressful). This one was quite nice though. Not too big, good and fresh food, stage for some entertainment. Cloths did not meet my quality expectations, but I assume that will be the case at all night markets.

The Night Market takes place Wednesday-Saturday nights. There's a stage for singing and dancing entertainment; there's lots of clothing to buy; there's an array of food stands with new things to try. Spend 15 minutes or two hours--it's great for people watching!
Completely underwhelmed by this place. Basically it's a market selling fake goods. No real local slant to it which was disappointing. We had hoped to find more stalls with local artifacts.
Better than the Russian Market....still same same but they had food stalls at great prices and you could sit on the ground amongst the locals. Clothing is cheaper here, I paid $2.50 for a dress.

the location is nearby Bus Terminal and Mekong River Side. Easily to find, can refer to the travel maps. I would to recommend the BBQ food, is cheaper than restaurant menu. Remember take care your wallet as well. Thank you.

I found these markets to be well organised and inexpensive. Many stalls are selling the same things but there is a bit of variety and I noticed prices for some items were cheaper than in the other markets in Phnom Penh. Most clothing was between $2 and $5. There is also some
I thought the night market would be full of crafts and arts and something authentic but it was like the same stuff you found at the Central Market. I was disappointed by the market.

I was there on business. So on the off chance that you have time. Go and get the best bargains. Note that if you are worried about the fakes. Most likely they are the genuine and clothing made in a cambodian factory. That is you can also be ripped . But go with eyes open. And

I had my phone and credit cards stolen in the throng of people in the narrow alleys of this market. There's nothing of interest here that can't be seen in other markets and local friends have said that it's got a reputation for being a tourist take down place. No real good
It is a nice experience seing a market like this. If you are in the area you must see all the things they are selling. It is impressive.

Local market not geared towards tourists. You can find cheap clothes, sunglasses, etc here if you need them. Aside from the clothes and things, you will find food vendors at the back with fresh spring rolls, noodles, and seafood of every variety. Prices are very reasonable and
A small market compared to others in town better visiting them than this one. Would only recommend if you are after a cheap meal the food is pretty good.

Went there tonight...very wet and very local. Sells mostly cheap looking knock offs and loads of watches. Food stalls selling pig ears and tongue skewers. Had some spring rolls...not the best. I would skip it and rather explore along the river where there is an amazing

On the night we went, mainly clothing stores and small section of food store. If u want fruits and fish and vege visit the old market. Just behind the night market This night mrk is not excellent according to my view
An average little market, if your looking for higher quality your better off to go to Central or the Russian market. If your on the riverside it's always worth checking this out at least one time.

There are umpteen markets in Phnom Penh, most of which operate during business hours, with only one whose formal purpose is to run at night. Located on Riverside, the Night Market opens on Fridays, Saturdays, and Sundays. Not only does the market provide diverse street food

For one dollar you can get a reasonable portion of food. Add $0.50 dollar for a drink. And your good. Enjoy your meal with the locals on the floor on a carpet. There is some live music. And some shopping in a market style.

Personally, I do not enjoy visiting the night markets. Probably because I can't fit into a size 6 dress. However, if you're looking for affordable clothes, or wanting to taste some local food, then this is the place for you. Occasionally they have live music and dance

It is a night market which selling lots of daily things include clothes, vegetables, fruit and so on. There are some tourists sit on picnic map and enjoy dinner as other local people. They looked enjoyable.
Best place to but t shirts and other souveniers. Only open thursday - sunday nights. Big stage with entertainment. 1 of my fave markets in phnom penh
Really loved going to night market. It is not as hot as day market. Much more shops are open on the night. You have stands around market selling all kinds of goods.
Great balance of clothing, wallets, bags etc. and food. At the back they had a really cool area where you could sit and eat. Very social and a fun, safe vibe. Would recommend.
I won't bother going. Better off with certain tralee market or Russian market. Unless of course you want to kill some time.
Small night market. Worth a quick look but nothing really interesting. Don't go out of your way to come here, good to walk to if it is nearby. Mostly catered to locals.
Small market, mostly for locals judging by the sizes, am 38 inch waist and wouldn't get a belt to fit, food court is good fun though and PJ;s Pizza was very good
We did a quick lap of this market. It's not bad but don't travel too far to see it as there isn't much there. Worth popping your head in to take a peek if you are in the area

My tuk tuk drove me here for food, however I walked through the market in 15 minutes and opted for food at Riverside. If there was 20 food places, they all had the exact same dishes. What was quite nice though, was the mats, where families and friends can sit and eat
Not bad although it has same food in every stall. Ambience is nice many locals and cheap food. To add there are plenty of cheap clothes.
Went to the night market expecting to find clothes and souvenirs but found nothing. Bad quality stuff. Nevertheless there are a lot of food stands were you can buy and eat right there, in the floor.

This place is a disappointment for me since I have been to several night and ready-to-wear markets. The goods being sold are a little bit expensive compared to Vietnam's and stalls pretty much clothes similar to each other. Modern clothing being sold look cheap. I wasn't able

The night market attracts many locals who go there to eat and shop. There are lots of street stalls selling food which is cooked in front of you and then you can sit on the mats in the middle of the square. Lovely atmosphere whilst you eat.

The night market is only open on weekends. Do try to come here for dinner at least once. In the evening, the food end of the market lays out rugs and carpets and you can order food there and take a seat on any one of the rugs. Literally, dining under the stars. A good
Just regular night market, been to many other much better ones, specially in Vietnam. I you have time on your hands, then you can plan a visit.
Small, only like t-shirts and watches to buy. Not much food either. Had some fried noodle with beef and it was good! If you are staying close you can get there to eat but if not - skip it.
Love this place. Fun to bargain hunt. Lots of bbq, grilled sea food etc. Be careful some vendors, usually women get mad when you bargain. They usually quote 3 to 4 times.
Things are pretty normal and just your normal night market. Clothes, performance and food. Clothes are pretty repetitive of what you will see at Ben Than market but cheaper . So - so .

The night market is an intense experience, but definitely worth in. On the weekends it is jam-packed with people and food stalls. The food for offer is great, and locals and tourists enjoy it alike. There are also some good bargains on small souvenirs and clothes.

The night market is a fun place to experience some culture. The stage and performers was entertaining to watch. And there is a huge variety of street food to choose from if your hungry. But my favorite part is weaving along the rows of business owners in each side selling

I stumbled on Night Market food court on Saturday night, probably the busiest time of the week. It was full of people, locals (families) and foreigners (mostly young) some seated on colorful mats placed in the central space on the ground (shoes left off mat), some on small
Able to find a few bargain tshirts and souvenirs. Refreshing shakes also. Lots of locals having dinner in the outdoor seating area.

I plan to come to night market because I need to travel like local people. Many people here are local people but some little for foreigner. There is shopping block and food street. But many people here so you should beware your belonging.

The night market is a small array of white tents, there are local stalls selling local food which you sit on mats on the floor to eat. The stalls are catered for the local population and not tourists. There are a lot of cheap clothes and shoes. It is not a place worth seeing.
Not really worth visiting. There is not much to do, not much to see and not too much too eat either. The karaoke was truly bad.
Nothing much to see compared to central market or Russian market. Pretty small night market with very limited choices. Always bargain.

The hotel warned us of pick pockets, but even so, I ended up having my wallet stolen out of a pocket with a snap. A group of about 6 cambodians pressed up against me in a crowd and before I could break free, they had gotten my wallet. My wife also got bumped hard and found a

I found these markets to be very relaxed - no-one grabbing and yelling. Yes, they try and convince you to buy (in the best tradition of markets) and they are happy to haggle for prices, but not too pushy. A lot of clothing is the same but walk around and check out the shows they
Clothes, clothes and clothes. Maybe other things, but mainly clothes. Just normal clothes. Aside from that, nice spot to eat some typical food and hear some loud but interesting performances.
Relatively small market offering snacks, clothing, flowers and local music. The market is set up in a circleIn the back there are straw mats on the ground for people

The Market is only open from 5pm till midnight. There is good and cheap food. Fried noodles are only $1. There is live entertainment at night [local Khmer talent]. Great place to shop if you are looking for the following 1)Clothes 2)Footwear 3) Counterfeit watches. There aren't

A nice little night market in PP that's worth a visit if you have time to kill before heading for food and drink along the quay to its south. Great food stalls that are yummy and cheap, so join in, get some food and sit with the locals.

Phnom penh's night market is not particularly impressive and only has a small selection of tourist junk to choose from. The market is very small and the sellers are normally pretty fed up of the tourists haggling over a few cents and are not usually In a good mood. However there
It's an ok place to meander around. Certainly wouldn't go out of my way to find it. You can find the things available for cheaper in the central market it seems, but the place has a nice buzz to it.

We had nothing planned so we got in a Tuk Tuk to check out the night market. Let's put it like this - being there was like having nothing planned. Cheap replicas and food that would make you diet. Sorry!

I saw exactly the same clothing and souvenirs in other night markets in Cambodia and Thailand. I mean, EXACTLY the same. There was this one dress with a banana print made of an unusual fabric that I remember having seen everywhere. Still, it was fun to go, wander around, people

Went to this market on a Sunday evening. Many clothing and other stalls to look at and buy cheap goods. Also had an area at one end to purchase a range of Khmer food and sit on mats to eat. Worth a visit but not great.

This market is situated over the road from the river and easy to get to and from. Has large stage and has entertainment as well as many shops selling clothes, food, gifts etc. there are many restaurants near by as well as many food vans. usually open Friday Saturday and Sunday

The night market had very limited selection and was essentially a giant outdoor mall. If looking for a market with handmade goods and gifts, check out the Russian market. There was some entertainment going on up on a stage while we were there, a skit Or comedy routine and many

We were a little disappointed with the night market. There were a lot stalls but mostly all were selling the same clothes, very limited selection. We were hoping to find a market with variety of different items but it just seemed to be clothes.

Real Khmer food, lots of locals and tourists but very cute place to sit around on mats and indulge in Khmer food, balut included. A lot of clothes and other stores full of cheap merchandise. A must see.

I've felt like back from to the past, people wore clothes like 15 years back, the music, the building, the area is in the middle of the market area, next to mekong river (black water's river) for food stall surrounding a big mat, place for you to eat on the street, joined other
If the central market is over rated then this place should be avoided at all costs. Nothing new, smaller scale than central market but a total waste of time. Opened Wednesday to Sunday nowadays.

Too many people for me. The market seems to be full of clothes and junk with hardly any room to walk between stalls. The best bit is the food stalls where you can pick up fried noodles and rice for less than a dollar.
It was a nice place to walk around at night, and they had a Cambodian comedian up on stage, but I wouldn't go out of the way to visit it.
We enjoyed wandering around the stalls but the highlight was the food. Delicious Indian and Khmer food, but the coconut ice-cream was some of the best I've tasted and believe me I've tasdted plenty
If you're in the neighborhood, it could be worth a look but compared to the other markets in town, it's nothing special.

... Give it 0 stars I would. This night market is horrible. They're trying to sell toys and that sort, more than souvies... The night market foods are pretty rank and unhygienic. I feel like I may get sick eating their foods here and this is coming from someone who tours food
We walked around for less than 30 mins. There is nothing special to buy or to see...food is very street food. Items are very cheap but not nice at all.

We ate at the stalls behind the live music stage at the Night Market. The clothing stalls etc are nothing special , but the food stalls were just fab. We had huge prawns, vegetables and noodles for less than $5 for 2 . There are rugs spread out in the square for you to sit and

Same stalls selling the same stuff as each other every week. Cheap crap that for the most part doesn't work and is poorly made. It's not even that cheap. Compared with other markets of this nature around the world, this doesn't come close to being one I want to visit again, even

I wouldn't say I'm Alan Whicker, but I have traveled around a bit and enjoy eating street food and visiting local Asian markets. This is rubbish. Some clothes stalls that you can find anywhere and a really poor food experience. The mats on the floor don't really do it for me and

I LOVE Asian markets but this one is a complete waste of time. Large part of the market is taken by a stage with locals singing karaoke so expect some blasting Cambodian pop songs. Like some other reviews said, all the food vendors sell exactly the same thing and it looks

Came here thinking the variety would be much more. Took a wander and to find most of the stuff is clothes geared towards the locals. Still nice to wander. At the end was a stage with a woman singing. She sounded like a female cat. Russian markets is better. If coming from SS buy

Spent about 10 minutes here and wanted to leave. I've eaten a lot of street food while traveling (I love street food!) and most of them looked clean enough to eat but this night market had the dirtiest food! Flies and other huge bugs were standing on most of the food and it

We stopped over here to change bus going to Siem Reap. Killed time by roaming around the small complex. It was just like any night market except the food section. Instead of chairs and tables they have woven mats spread on the floor. We crossed our legs and enjoyed our meal with
Interesting place to visit but very crowded. Better bargains at the Central Market. Has a nice stage and saw some local talent.
Go ounce just to see but after 5min its enought, good if you want to buy some tshirts (2/3$). Food was all the same, seems like the street food is better on the side streets around the market

We visited here the 6th December after we had been on a sunset dinner/cocktail cruise as it was just over the road from where we got off the boat. It was quite busy by the time we got there, it was alright but nothing special, very noisy with loud music and lots of locals, would
This market is focused on clothing, not so much on souvenirs. And also it is relatively small. Sellers seem bored.
Great streetfood! And cheap. Some shopping poss for clothes, shoes, watches and other stuff but we went for the great streetfood. For 2 to 4 dollar you have a great meal!
Cheap street food and concerts every day. Also, it has a small market with affordable clothes and accessories. If you just arrived in Phnom Penh this place can show you original Asian life,

Visited this night market as not far from the hotel and although the stalls offered nothing new compared to the Russian and Central markets, the food section was good and we had a delicious self-selection of snacks with a bowl of noodle soup for $4 each.
It is OK but not very extensive. We bought some clothing and a leather belt. Not as good as the Central market, but I found that late at night they were more willing to bargain.
The market is ok, nice to see at night and take cheap souvenirs Many people, many times you ve singers ( cambodian bands ) or theather, Good to visit.

The variety of items at the market is lacking - more of a tourist market. There are some good prices on clothes (keeping in mind sizes here are drastically different than in the Western world. I am 5'5" and 115 lbs, and I would not buy anything smaller than a Large or even XL

Phnom Penh's night market is a bustling, market right on the river in the centre of the city. People, motorbikes, taxis, Tuk Tuks & tourists are everywhere! We went on a Friday night & while we didn't stay too late, it had the feel of a place you could hang around in till late!

Not the best markets in PP. Very touristy, no much locally produced items. Probably the best part is the food and the area set aside for people to sit on the ground and enjoy their meal. If that's your thing, you'll enjoy the night markets, otherwise have a walk around and do

This Night Market is a very interesting place where you can buy almost anything. It is situated in a very convenient right on Riverside. It used to be open only on Friday, Saturday and Sunday nights, but I understand it now opens on Thursdays already. usually very crowded and
Lots of clothes and fake watches, a vaguely interesting area for eating sitting on mats. We preferred wandering the surrounding streets.

The first night market (Phsar ri-trey in Khmer) in Phnom Penh city, Cambodia where it opens at the weekend (Fri-Sun) from the evening time, 5pm onward. You can taste Cambodian made snack, drinks, and clothes there. The place you can enjoy walking around the riverside as well.

Stopped by here as love a night market, but it was very small and there was really only clothes on sale (the same ones as you get everywhere else). The street food stalls looked really good and the selection was impressive and smelt amazing, so would mainly recommend for that.

as a night market I found it very plain and boring, also VERY small...but then you have a really cool part where you can get all sorts of food and sweets...I tried the fried oreo...amazing XD so I would reccomend it for that reason, get your dinner, grab a beer and just lay down

It is a market which opens at 5pm. Sometimes there is a band, very little handicrafts. Probably great if it is your first night in PP, but I never bring my guests there. No deals to be made, all is cheap bling bling.
enjoyable, nice people, good prices and articles, lots of people, good food, great concerts , be prepared to bargain a lot!

The Night Market is open on weekends with a claustrophobic number of merchandise stalls and food vendors, and there are some good, authentic Khmer restaurants just across the street. Live entertainment on the main stage is common. The stalls often overlap in what they sell but

The product is similar to the Central day markets - but if you don't have time during the day this is worthwhile . I found you pay a little bit extra at the night market than you do during the day, but that could just be the timing and what else had been sold. Paid more for

This was the first place we visited after arriving in Cambodia. We didn't really know what to expect which was good as we went with an open mind. The market was cramped & had lots of stalls, mostly selling the same sort of things but it was our first night so we just fancied a
A nice place to go on weekends! Crafts, food, nice people, genuine s,iles and a spell of inocence lies there! I just like so much this place!

In my experience, the Night Market here is almost the same with the Night Market in Vietnam or Laos. The food section might be different. I ordered a chicken noodle for 1.5USD and it’s our first time to experience sitting on mat to eat in public (instead of tables and chairs).
Really enjoyed this market had a little bit of everything, good to see nice walk around, preferred the indoor market more variety and better prices

At the end of Sisowath quay, you cross the road, to find this Night Market. The makeshift shops sell mostly clothes, bags and shows, there are a few souvenir shops as well. There is a area in the middle where people buy food, sit on the mats and eat. This market is thronged

It's a lot smaller compared to central market. Generally, the shops are full of clothes that would not appeal to westerners. It is open from 5pm till midnight, Wednesday-Sunday. It may be good if your interested in Cambodian food as there is a few food stalls at the back of the

If your are a tourist looking for a few things to take home as gifts this would be the place. I find it a bit uninteresting with many stalls selling watches, handicrafts and clothes. There is a stage which puts on entertainment some nights. I did find the food area very

cute little night market lots of clothes and craft stores, nice little food court situated at the back with sitting/eating area, very cheap, my favourite part is the big stage they have set up with performers full of local khmer people, its on every friday/saturday/sunday, but i
Lots of cheap jeans and clothes that most tourists wouldn't likely want. Central Market has that and much more including lots of photo ops of the fruit, veg and fish stalls, souvenirs etc.
Not really my cup of tea. Very touristy but they had a great singer when I visited. Look for other markets for the real stuff

Hiked from our hotel to this night market and saw a band was playing some Cambodian music. There were a lot of people either eating or looking for some stuff. We bought our pajamas here after a lot of haggling from the vendor. NIce place to visit. You can check out my blog about

On our travels we went through the Russian market, and the Central Market, but the Night Market was the best... Everything was soooo cheap, compared to the other markets, not as much variety though as it is much smaller..

Great place to eat, a cool experience for foreigners. It has mats laid out on the ground to sit on. The shopping is less than impressive, it is small with little variety. The live music was off key and too loud, but I don't know if that was nightly or a special ordeal.

This place is located near mekong river.Open from 5 pm till 10 pm.They sell clothes,bags,shoes and foods as well.The quality of stuff is so so,some are good as u can find in russian market. If u like cheap n good quality items,better to go to Russian Market.Its ok just to

We took a tuk tuk to there cost us $3. Great place to get cheap dinner. And buy souvenirs. Always bargain, you could get at least 25% off!!! But be realistic and polite. Saw a pommy lady shouting at a vendor which I think is pretty rude. After all they are trying to make a

For the seasoned traveller who has been to night markets all over Asia, this particular market has probably the least to offer. It is just the same goods (mainly imitation wares) repeated at each stall. It gets really crowded and warm at night which is what makes it a haven

its a night market which starts at 6 pm to 10.pm from Thursday till Sunday . usually one can find alot of clothes shirts pants pajamas, bed sheets , table covers and kick off souvenirs like dragons flowers Buddha statues and snake wine etc, recommended time duration would be
Interesting to have a browse around, but if you've been to one market you've been to them all. There are also food stalls where you can purchase food and sit on the mats.
This market opens at 5 pm on Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays only. T-Shirts, shorts, footwear etc. Prices are roughly $2-$3 for all types of clothes so it's pretty good to go there and stock up!

On our last night we took a trip here for last minute shopping. My daughters bought pyjamas and jeans for $2.50. They were excellent for the price and were a little different to Australia. There is music playing, food to eat and it was a pretty relaxed atmosphere. All in all,

It was a bit hurried, but we spend about two hours at the market, looking curiously at the crowd and all the wares for sale. My friend bought a straw hat and light sandals for our next destinations. With all the milling crowds of young people, one feels new life surging through

Ok first, you can buy any of a number of great things to eat. There is an amazing party vibe that is so Southeast Asian it couldn't be anything else. Pubs serving great drinks everywhere, tons of things to buy and look at. An amazing river with a beautiful little bridge... Yea.
It is quite an experience to shop at a night market. It's like attending a carnival back home. People are friendly, and the lights add to the excitement.
This was an amazing new experience for me. I learned how to barter and I enjoyed all the colors and variety.

Nice outdoor market, with lots of clothes, belts, scarves, wallets, and costume jewelry. Good place for t-shirts and hippy pants. Did more people watching than shopping, however. Lots of locals eating, shopping and enjoying life. Great to see! Kept a close watch on our

We go night market and try local food , omg we get sick one week after eating diner , really terrible , when I seen her cooking and make drink , no never and ever again , if u want try need bring medicine together

Basic and lack the buzz you get with a night market. Food stalls seems to serve all the same things. Other stalls do not stock products of appeal. You get better energy by walking in the Old Market in the adjoining streets.

It's a busy street but compared to other ones in Asia it's considered less crowded and easy to walk around, as there aren't many streets that cross along the shopping area, walk up and down most of the shops are selling the same. If you are buying a hammek I would recommend you

This is a smaller market and I was looking forward to leisurely wander around. I did for the first half an hour and then disaster strike. Never felt a thing to start with then turned around and my back pack had been opened both top zip and purse taken and main zip open. Nothing

I have traveled to SE Asia regularly over the past 5 years and thoroughly enjoy hitting the world class night markets. This place however is NOT one of them for several reasons: A) Their Is a profesional Pickpocket ring that operates here , they took my phone in about 5 minutes
If you're looking for decent quality t-shirts or belts, this is a good, fun place for a couple hours. With a warning, they cater for local sizes only, so if you're more than a "M" you're out of luck.

Doesn't really compare on scale with some of the other night markets in SE Asia, but you might as well take a look round. Most of it is clothing with the odd souvenir / jewellery stall. Was very busy when we went, keep an eye on your possessions.

We went to the night market at about 6:30pm just after the sun had set. There was many stalls but almost all of them where women's clothes. You do need to fight your way through the crowds but it is less hectic than the Russian market. Enjoy !
just as normal flea market nothing special. if you expect to find some souvenir, origin from Cambodia, you can not find it here.

This market is a little small compared to others in SE Asia, but I had a really good time here nonetheless. I'm not much of a shopper, but my girlfriend loves to shop and had a good time searching around for some good bargains on clothes. I was able to occupy myself with some
Walked through inabout 15min. Waste of time. Not worth seeing. Go to theRussian Market instead. Unless you need women's clothes.

souvenirs, clothes, street food. Not to many attraction I found here. also the price are higher than traditional market in town. But if you stay in the riverside area and not be able going explore the other market in the city then this place is enough.
Better deals in the Central and Russian market, but interesting stop on the weekends. Same spread as the other markets though.

I was surprised that this Night Market really has almost nothing of interest. Almost entirely low-quality clothes, some shoes and bags, and a few places selling food. I didn't see anything interesting, to be honest. Wandered about for 10-15 minutes and headed south for a beer

the last time I was here it was only open on weekends. This year we went on a weekday and had fun and got good bargains.the food served there can be kind of hectic to order and you don't really know what's going to cost you.
Go with an open mind and try some of the food. Lots of interesting options. We really enjoyed wandering around and enjoying the environment.
The Night market opens every Friday to Sunday at night. Lots of clothes and very good local food. We have been there yesterday and gonna go today as well.
Pros: * Cool variety of stuff available * Friendly vendors open to bargaining * Ample spots for grabbing a quick snack Cons: * If you're a foreigner and not cautious, vendors tend to over-quote
I want to know more about the Hair in cambodia. Can someone help me? Someone who lives in cambodia please

Busy and crowded night market. Can bargain but don't too much. Buy some souvenir like scarf and the carving products. There got the coconut ice cream and it cost $1, it's nice :) u can find a seat as there has provided the mat and u can mingle with the locals.

Phnom Penh Night Market is just in Sisowath Quay. I got to shop here and use my haggling tactics to purchase some souvenirs and footwear. Food is also available and a great place to mingle with locals. They also have programs being shown to everyone in the market.

This place is real just for the locals to catch up and eat together, nothing really to buy there. Wasn't memorable at all. They did sell "chicken bum" at one food vendor - that was my high light so that's saying something.

I've been here long time ago, it's just an open air night market, nothing special to see except some stalls and very busy and crowded place, during the day it's like an open empty space, and if you don't know that the market it's there you'll probably miss it.

I found the night market in Phnom Penh particularly interesting to blend with the locals and have some nice street food. A big food arena is set up and there are more locals then foreigners, the food is cheap and tasty. I would recommend to stop by one evening!
Night market is crazy busy but well worth a look. Great local food and clothing. Remember this is where the locals buy their clothes so its hot sweaty and hectic....but a must do.

If you want to rub shoulders with the locals this is the place to be. It is crowded and you are shoulder to shoulder all the time. You will not see any foreigners all the time you are there. Why tourists miss out on this experience I do not know. There are plenty of clothing
Nothing really interesting there unless you like flip flops. The market seems like it's for locals because the market only had off brand shoes and clothes.

Very crowded stalls close together. If you don't mind a crush of people there is a lot to see. Many locals but also a tourist spot. Great people watching. Make sure you hold your purse or bags close to you.

This is my favourite market in Cambodia....it has food, entertainment, and shopping. By far better prices than Central Market and the Russian Market. A good variety of clothing, shoes, and souvenirs, at decent prices.

The same selection of wares as will be found at Russian and Central markets anecdotally at higher price. Rather uninspiring but may be worth a visit combined with eating at variety of stalls within the marketplace and can sit on mats on floor. Possibly better quality and
Really great local foodie experience. Choose from a variety of fried food or noodles. friendly staff who bring your food to you on the communal mats on the floor.

This market is pretty manic at night, with cars, SUVs and people jostling for room on the street along with hundreds of happy eaters attacking the freshly cooked - mostly before your own eyes - food. Fresh fish is abundant as is bbq, noodles, rice and lots more.

Didn't really find anything that great at the night markets. Much preferred Central Market or Russian Market. However, I had the most amazing coconut ice cream here, so if you like coconut ice cream go search for it here!!

This is a rather small night market. A bit touristic, and less interesting than most of the day markets here.

A relatively small night market, only open on Friday, Saturday and Sunday evenings, selling a limited range of shirts, scarves, cosmetics and food. Very loud live music all-pervading. There are certainly better markets in Phnom Penh and Siem Reap, but worth an hour's wandering

foods and drinks will cost around $ 2-3 each, located at the back side. start to open in the afternoon and sometimes they have live singer on stage. you can choose to eat on the big rug in the middle of the court, mingle with local, or use few tables at the side of the court.

This market is situated in a central area, in walking distance from the King's Palace and next to the promenade. It offers a rich choice of cheap textile items, jewelry and souvenirs. The night market is worth visiting even if you don't plan shopping, just for the ambiance.
Average at best for a night market. But some stalls do have delicious food and drink. Ok of you have an hour to kill which will be easy in this city.

I really enjoyed the atmosphere of these markets, it was very busy and has a good selection of cambodian delights and heaps of shopping stalls with something for everyone , also there is sometimes a band playing while you eat.

The usual array of stuff you would expect in a night market, b with a higher than usual focus on not-quite-designer clothing. Haggling didn't seem to be on the menu for some stall holders here; for a wider variety and happier stall holders go to the Russian market.
